text: the government yesterday hit back over claims that children of working mothers suffer academically and insisted it was taking steps to help parents balance work and home life the employment and equal opportunities minister margaret hodge rejected suggestions made in last nights panorama programme that children of preschool age whose mothers work later achieve worse reading scores ministers have also been stung by a study for the same programme indicating onethird of mothers are forced out of fulltime working with many blaming inflexible employers for failing to allow them necessary time off work those findings gave ammunition to campaigners including trade unions who while backing the governments pledge to give mothers who want to work new choices insist that it has so far done too little to compel employers to help women return to the workplace they will also be taken up by critics who argue tony blairs administration is seeking to force mothers back into employment ms hodge rejected a study by professor heather joshi of the institute of education which suggested children were around a tenth less likely to advance one academic stage if their mothers worked during their preschool years she said this research is based on a time when nobody thought about childcare as a national issue we now know perfectly well that it is choice and quality of childcare which are crucial to childrens academic outcomes the government faces more pressure to make a reality of promises to improve homelife balance for employees from the tuc and other pressure groups they are are urging legislation to ensure employers offer parents real choices to allow them to return to work ms hodge yesterday announced the creation of an advisory committee whose members include former observer editor will hutton and the author shirley conran to brainstorm new ways to transform work culture in britain

text: a third of working mothers are quitting fulltime jobs for parttime positions or giving up work altogether a survey reveals today with many women blaming inflexible employers who refuse to allow them time off to look after their children the research carried out for the bbcs panorama programme undermines government initiatives which are aimed at encouraging women who have had children to return to the workforce researchers at the university of bristol who analysed the working patterns of mothers found that they all returned to work fulltime after the birth of their first child but within two years more than a third had given up their fulltime positions with switching to parttime employment and giving up work altogether the programme makers also commissioned a smallerscale study of mothers taken from the ongoing british household panel survey which examined the reasons why such a high proportion of mothers are leaving fulltime work susan harkness of the university of sussex who carried out the research said i think we tended to assume that those women whod come back to work after childbirth stay in the labour market so the scale of the dropout was really quite surprising we found that women who returned to fulltime work tended to do so when their children were very young we also found they worked very long hours there was no reduction in hours prior to and after the birth of the child so there was no accommodation within their jobs to account for the fact they now had responsibilities for a very young child one of the women interviewed was cathy schofield who gave up her job as marketing director for a publishing firm in order to be able to spend more time with her son i didnt think i would find myself not exactly being hounded out of work but having my working day made so guiltridden that i just couldnt bear to carry on the publishing company insist they were accommodating but ms schofield says her boss complained when her son was ill saying he seemed to be ill more often than other children and when she stayed at home to deal with an emergency her holiday allowance was docked penny gillison a new mother has been trying to negotiate flexible working hours with her boss to cope with looking after her child you always have this feeling that someones saying in the background oh youre a terrible mother how dare you work i have no choice at this point in time while encouraging mothers back into the workplace has become a key plank of government policy critics say much more needs to be done including legislation that would impose the legal right for new mothers to demand their old job back on a parttime basis however any such move would be fiercely opposed by employers ruth lea of the institute of directors said we did a survey months ago of our members and of them said that they would think twice about taking on women of prime childbearing age because of the maternity legislation the programme called back to the kitchen sink which will be broadcast at pm tonight on bbc also looks at the latest research into child development which appears to add weight to the controversial theory that young children whose parents work full time may perform less well at school professor heather joshi of the institute of education analysed several aspects of the lives of young adults who were born in the research found there was a link between a mothers employment in the preschool years and their childrens academic success the differences were small but meant that girls were less likely to advance one rung of the qualifications ladder such as the step between gcse and alevel while boys were less likely to do so the results follow the findings of the first part of the study released three months ago which reported that children whose mothers worked before they were one year old had slightly worse reading scores later on there may be something in the childs early development that equips them better to face these undoubted challenges of doing public exams professor joshi said however researchers believe of more significance may be the quality of childcare rather than simply the fact of having a working mother

text: for the first months of your childs life you want to be at home without chucking your career out of the window you are a parent working fulltime but you need to pick up your children from school or nursery each day you are bringing up children alone and if one of them is sick and off school you have no option but to skip work these are the daily dilemmas facing the average working parent but lets be honest when we say parent we really mean woman for despite a raft of family friendly government policies new technology and the emergence of a socalled softer management style women are still bearing the brunt of childcare responsibility and are forced into making unhappy compromises between home office and children traditionally family pressures have often dictated the type of work women undertake the secretarial sector has always attracted huge numbers of women not least because its hours have been relatively childfriendly but the dramatic change in the secretarial role combined with a fitter and faster workplace has conspired to make any job a juggling act of home and work pressures its not a joyful task a survey by lloydstsb revealed this month that in the last quarter of the th century working mothers were the most dissatisfied group of people in society thanks to the pressures of running a modern family wendy neusone who has a twoyear old son and works as a fulltime secretary for the legal department of the equal opportunities commission knows those pressures too well i set my standards quite high and i dont like to mention it if something goes wrong at home she says you do worry in case its looked on badly my husband is away on business a lot because he is a sales rep and although he helps where he can nine times out of ten the burden falls on me it can be a struggle to balance it all the government has changed the law to make it easier for women and especially lone parents to stay at work the working family tax credit allows eligible parents to claim up to of childcare costs but with the average yearly cost for two children in fulltime care around returning to work is still not economically feasible for many women earning middle or lower incomes campaigners argue that the only effective way to help working parents is to provide adequate childcare facilities but currently only one in ten employers offer any kind of help from creches to information service lines so what if you could pick and choose your working hours neusone for instance works flexitime which allows her to beat the rushhour traffic and pick up her son before pm when his nursery shuts flexibility is the latest buzzword and new patterns are attracting working parents since flexitime allows employees to choose within set limits the times they start and finish work parttime employment jobsharing and working from home are now protected by law and are attracting both men and women but many employers resist the idea of a more fluid and flexible workforce and workers in support roles are by definition often less free to design their own working schedules they often need to shadow the hours of their bosses who may be hostile to flexitime or jobshare initiatives for the employer its the continuity factor says ruth lea head of policy at the institute of directors employees have responsibilities as well as rights if youre a pa to a gogetting chap or woman youve got to be there she argues that recent legislation has only made it harder for women to break through the glass ceiling when we surveyed our members said they found women of childbearing age less attractive to employ than other groups basically youve got to make a hard choice the future is not female the truth is if you are talking about the workplace there are a lot of constrictions and limitations her assessment is shocking partly because it contrasts so sharply with the language of empowerment usually employed about working parents and instead of believing the workplace will become more familyfriendly she thinks the future will be surprisingly similar to the present childcare believes lea is entirely the responsibility of the worker when employers take people on they know about their family commitments but they expect them to be adult enough to be able to handle these pressures themselves its not up to us to do it that view was painfully illustrated last week when a city lawyer won her case for unfair dismissal after contending that her boss deliberately increased her workload when she first became pregnant and sacked her when she had her fourth child even though aisling sykes was prepared to take work home to carry on her hour day her employer jp morgan wanted her in the office having children sykes claimed was considered a lifestyle choice like playing squash if the sykes case is an exceptional example she was after all able to afford three fulltime nannies her dilemma does reflect a worrying trend merryn wells advice services manager for the equal opportunities commission tells the story of a pregnant pa who was forced to quit her job when she asked for a little compromise she used to work long hours but once she got pregnant she asked her employer if she could work her contractual hours am to pm basically the employer said no so she tried to work fulltime after the birth and could not cope she felt she had no choice but to resign carolyn jones director of the institute of employment rights is depressed by this climate i think back to when the former labour prime minister harold wilson talked about the white heat revolution of technology predicting it would bring more leisure and family time something has gone wrong today we are working longer hours for less pay and less leisure time she argues that a flexible workforce makes business sense if you adapt the workplace to the workers you get a more committed team because they are not spending most of their energy simply juggling their lives the culture and expectation is now about seeing the person as a whole and recognising their broader lifestyles some companies do take a progressive approach local authorities the nhs charities and it companies for example are known for their pragmatic approach to working practices at british telecom jobsharing is particularly common among its administrative staff the vast majority of whom are women in the next office one of our directors has two secretaries who jobshare says a spokesperson they are both married with children and they swap jobs as commitments come up it provides that necessary continuity and the manager is happy

text: cherie booth yesterday accused her husbands government of breaking european law by excluding millions of parents from new rights to take leave in legal advice prepared for the tuc ms booth a qc in employment law says tony blairs administration is in breach of the eu parental leave directive which guarantees all parents up to weeks unpaid leave because parents of children now under five will not benefit on the basis of her advice the tuc executive yesterday decided on a legal challenge to the british regulations brought in by the trade and industry secretary stephen byers ms booth who is expecting her fourth child insisted her opinion was given to the tuc to protect the government rather than find fault with it the exclusion of million parents she wrote cannot be justified by the need for flexibility and the european directive does seem to have been misimplemented under mr byerss regulations all mothers fathers and adoptive parents have the right to take up to weeks unpaid leave during the first five years of a childs life but only for children born on or after december last year the deadline for implementing the eu directive the argument is over parents with children under five born before the december cutoff date the european commission is due to rule next month on a less stringent restriction by ireland which applied the right to parents of children born after the date when the directive was passed in and is expected to find it unlawful john monks the tucs general secretary said last night he hoped the government would now recognise the force of the legal arguments and extend unpaid parental leave to the parents of all underfives the trade and industry department said the government remained convinced there was no requirement under european law to extend the rights

text: the main difference in being old is that we can have a bit more leisure a bit more choice about what we do with ourselves we are given a precious last chance if only we can avoid poverty to cure ourselves of the pandemic hurry sickness before we subside into rest we even have a little time to experience education for educations sake not because it will qualify us for a more monied and a more hectic life but life cannot be given over entirely to the delights of nonvocational education and to relief from the pressures of a competitive market new pleasures are being combined with new duties particularly because ever increasing numbers of grandparents are becoming more involved with the rearing of grandchildren than they were and some are becoming active parents for a second time round the need is obvious marriage has become less popular divorce more so there are more and more single parents and above all more children in distress because their parents have broken apart some geneticists consider that women experience the menopause in order that they can assist in the survival of their descendants who are not their children but their grandchildren ample evidence for the growing modern practice comes not from britain but as so often from the us a report by the us census bureau last year showed that m grandparents live with their grandchildren and this does not include the millions more who are in one way or another caring for grandchildren without actually living with them out of the m grandparents m are raising them in their own home one million others are living with their grandchildren because they need to play an active part in supporting them climbing divorce rates teenage pregnancies and drug use are cited as the main reasons for grandparents being in a supportive role the us is fortunate in having a more impressive array of support groups than in britain there are between and active local grandparent groups which provide all manner of services for their members including representing them to the local authorities in addition there are strong grandparent lobbies at washington and in individual states the politically powerful american association of retired persons with more than m members is taking an interest in its grandparent members and more financial support is coming to those in poverty the part played by grandparents is generally respected and acknowledged in the us they are seen as an indispensable resource for children who would otherwise be parentless social workers in the us also hold the view distinct from their counterparts in britain that grandparents should be considered first although they are of course not always suitable as foster parents the old myth lingers in britain that if the parents have in some way failed it must be the fault of the grandparents in not bringing up their own children well enough creating a sort of guilt by association which is quite unjustified a recent report from the child welfare league of america spells out the advantages apart from avoiding the stigma of being a foster child for the children being cared for by relatives enabling children to live with persons whom they know and trust reducing the trauma children may experience when they are placed with persons who initially are unknown to them reinforcing childrens sense of identity and selfesteem facilitating childrens connections to their siblings encouraging families to consider and rely on their own family members as resources enhancing childrens opportunities to stay connected to their own communities and promoting community responsibility for children and families strengthening the ability of families to give children the support they need there are english exceptions of course in plymouth for example the city councils social services department has taken an interest one of their social workers david pitcher published a report in called when grandparents care he interviewed grandparents who had their grandchildren living with them after a case conference or court had found there was a risk of abuse as long as the child remained in the parental home it was not always easy going for the grandparents they did not have as much energy for rough and tumble and dealing with schools as when they were younger the grandchildren could be less respectful towards them and drugs and violence in the streets were common concerns but the comments were overwhelmingly favourable ranging from theyve kept me young to whatever price ive had to pay its been worth it in britain the first full study of grandparenting using a large representative sample has just been completed by geoff dench of the institute of community studies in conjunction with the national centre for social research the results show that the proportion of children living with grandparents is much lower in britain than in the us but in all sorts of other ways the grandparents of britain are doing a great deal for their grandchildren especially when the parental family is breaking up the evidence begs certain questions why grandparents are not paid when they step in in some instances giving up work to make caring possible and why do they get nothing extra for grandchild care even when the grandparents are on income support what we are seeing is a revival in the importance of the extended family this is going on alongside a vital change in its structure when studies of families in bethnal green in the east end of london were first being done in the s the extended family had a very large lateral extension some people had dozens even hundreds of relatives living locally married brothers and sisters and their nephews and nieces and all the inlaws children were surrounded by aunts and uncles and cousins of different degrees as fertility has continued to fall and families have become smaller the lateral has given way to the vertical more people live longer so there are more grandparents lasting longer and more greatgrandparents still alive the uncles and aunts have to some extent been replaced by the grandparents and when there are stepchildren the numbers of grandparents a child possesses can be more than four a new crossgenerational extended family is coming into existence this new kind of family pattern has profound consequences for the society of the new century alongside the more traditional family there will be growing numbers of grandparent grandchild families taking over from the parents who are bearers of the children many parentgrandparent agreements are made individually wherever both parties are willing parents might be working and have some freedom while they are still relatively young and not take on parental responsibilities until later meanwhile there is much that can be done by government if it is willing to support grandparents the children act of recognised that grandparents are family as a result some children who would otherwise be institutionalised in homes or placed with unrelated foster parents have been placed with grandparents instead but the policy is still very patchy a good deal has also been done to provide finance for childcare but although grandparents commonly act as child carers when their sons or daughters are working they cannot receive any allowance for all that they do even if they are on income support themselves there are hundreds of ridiculous anomalies for instance why should grandparents be unable to get help with travel expenses to visit children in prison when a host of other relatives are eligible the most important point to make about policy is about proximity grandparents cannot support parents effectively unless they live near each other housing policy has divided families millions of them since the war so that sons and daughters are rehoused all over the place without any consideration for links of kinship if some of the discrimination against grandparents were removed addressing the problem of splitting families geographically could be the beginning of a government policy which recognises the full role that grandparents play in the lives of their grandchildren michael young lord young of dartington is a sociologist and the author with peter willmott of family and kinship in east london and of the rise of meritocracy jean stogdon a former manager in camden social services is presently a guardian ad litem an independent childcare agent appointed in public law cases to give an assessment of a childs best interest

text: when it comes to listing key differences between the sexes attitude to debt could probably rank alongside physiognomy and leg waxing as being gender specific debt advice agencies say more women than men use their services and in the case of national debtline per cent of callers are women the consumer credit counselling service reports that per cent of its clients are female but this doesnt mean women are running up more debts than men a woman may be administering a family debt burden as part of her responsibility for household bills men do have their financial strengths however cumulative research shows men more willing to take risks with money as with other things which may lead to greater returns women will avoid risk and thereby returns in return for security research also shows women as more debt intolerant than men so more likely to seek help and seek it sooner i think women are more sensitive to what other people think and debt has a stigma said sophie brookes at national debtline women may also be dealing with an unfortunate sexual birthright if you want to be poor be a woman says economic psychologist professor stephen lea at exeter university women bringing up children alone invariably face financial hardship but poor does not have to mean being a povertystricken single parent lea says it can simply mean being at the bottom of the income group you think you belong to debt accumulated this way may be progressive and a problem only if circumstances change a relationship breaking down say or job loss but if you iron out any sexual weighting women are probably better with money than men weve carried out student debt studies for the best part of years where you can more or less equal out income and essential spending says professor lea in those circumstances women are less likely to be in debt and have lower debts when they are my very strong guess is that where you compare like with like women have the better financial attitude yet the latest british lifestyles survey from mintel reveals that per cent of men regard reducing debt as a priority compared with per cent of women a higher percentage of men than women saw saving as a priority reflecting renewed consumer confidence both sexes were more likely to spend on themselves but women also showed a marked increase in spending on the home per cent against per cent for men the fact that women have this strong bond with their home environment which may be stronger still if they have children may also be part of their debt downfall they may see debt as something difficult to run away from the other key question is whether women in their eagerness to control their home and its budget may also push their partners out of the financial loop claire kelly who now runs the bicester citizens advice bureau has been a money adviser for years she says when you start a relationship it tends to be the woman who deals with money and that role progresses when a financial problem arises the woman continues in her role as money manager but coping with debt often involves reeducation recognising that there is a problem and changing spending patterns if one partner is left out of this process their spending patterns and financial awareness may not change this is perhaps borne out by research into among lowincome families by ruth lister professor of social policy at loughborough university she found that men may actually obstruct womens attempts to keep their families out of debt by quietly running up other debts we certainly found evidence of store cards being used this way to subvert control she says its very important to get advice says kelly but if you are in a relationship it would be better to deal with it as a couple there is potentially a problem if text: who holds the key to key to getting the most out of your first or second job its you of course but there is another keyholder your boss and as anyone who has ever worked for a poor manager will testify a boss who lacks the basic set of management skills can soon sap you of all enthusiasm and motivation but what makes a good manager good leadership qualities inspirational creativity a direct line to the boardroom sex yes sex the sex of your boss may be more of a factor than anything else women managers are a small but growing minority in less than of managers in the country were women while today that figure stands at according to figures from analyst remuneration economics women managers also happen to be more efficient and trustworthy have a better understanding of their workforce and are more generous with their praise in short they make the best managers and if male bosses are to keep up they will have to start learning from their female counterparts a dangerous and inflammatory supposition maybe but all the research points towards such a conclusion a survey published at the end of last year by management today magazine serves as an indictment of the ability of male bosses to function as leaders in the modern workplace a majority of those questioned male and female managers across the uk believed women had a more modern outlook on their profession and were more open minded and considerate by way of contrast a similar number believe male managers are egocentric and more likely to steal credit for work done by others more than of those surveyed said men did not make better bosses than women female managers use time more effectively with many of those surveyed commenting that juggling commitments is a familiar practice for women with a home and a family most of us can probably identify at least one woman who attributes her success to an ability to be just like the men after years of having to adopt a masculine identity and hide their emotions and natural behaviour in the workplace it seems female bosses have become more comfortable with using their own style as a way to move forward so much so that women have now become the role models for managers the uk findings tally with a survey of female bosses carried out in the us a fiveyear study of managers from firms found that many male bosses were rated by staff of both sexes to be ministers believe the scheme under which the employment service would act as a giant temping agency would help ease the burden on business of new familyfriendly working regulations by bypassing recruitment costs the plan is also intended to provide flexible work opportunities for skilled professionals particularly mothers who may have dropped out of fulltime employment after having children the trade and industry secretary stephen byers is to examine the plan as part of his consultation on maternity pay and leave announced in last weeks budget and launched with a meeting of whitehall officials yesterday the review is certain to lead to improved rights possibly including longer leave and more time off for fathers potentially putting the government on a collision course with businesses already complaining of overregulation the supertemp scheme would create a pool of skilled temporary workers in specialist fields such as accountancy it or management whose details would be held by local employment service offices workers would be able to state their skills and the times they were able to work perhaps stipulating school terms only small and mediumsized companies needing cover when permanent staff took time off would be able to contact the service to find workers to match their needs saving on the cost of advertising and recruitment businesses complain that finding temporary workers is a key hidden cost of new rights such as parental leave under which parents of children under five can take up to weeks off work unpaid bt estimates its recruitment costs at per worker while the institute of personnel and employment calculates the cost of replacing a junior manager at the minister for women tessa jowell has commissioned the employment service to examine how the scheme will work and is strongly backing the proposal ministers argue that it will kill two birds with one stone by providing practical help for businesses coping with the costs of improved parental rights while offering flexible work options for parents who do not want to work full time other workers expected to be keen to become supertemps are professionals who retire early and find they wish to keep in touch with the workplace and mothers who wish to return to work once their children are older ministers are also considering using the scheme as a gateway to training to help wouldbe temps update skills to match employers needs precisely a government source said one advantage of this is that companies would be more predisposed to any extension of maternity leave if we have shown them beforehand that the government really does want to help them and not simply apply pressure the intention is to make any changes easier for businesses to handle the british chambers of commerce last night welcomed the proposal as a step on the way to easing the potential burden for business of new maternity rights but said more support would be needed to compensate small firms for extra costs spokesman andrew parkinson said its encouraging that the government is now thinking about the answers before proposing the problems in order to sweeten the pill that is something that text: working mothers could get the automatic right to return to their jobs parttime after taking maternity leave under plans being considered by the government female ministers are pressing the trade and industry secretary stephen byers to bring in the reform which would delight vocal campaigners for a better balance between work and family life in a move announced in this weeks budget with an eye on winning womens votes mr byers will consult on improving maternity pay and rights there is also strong pressure for a new right to unpaid parental leave for both mothers and fathers to be paid employment minister margaret hodge and womens ministers lady jay and tessa jowell are thought to back the change although mr byers is wary of a negative reaction from employers campaigners say the review marks an opportunity to improve the maternity deal for british mothers who are entitled to the equivalent of weeks off on full pay compared with a european average of weeks lucy anderson a tuc equal rights officer said the most effective way to keep women in touch with the labour market after having children is to increase the coverage of statutory maternity pay and maternity allowance one senior female minister said we are digging in our heels on this and we are being heard clear signals from female ministers particularly in the treasury and department of education and employment that such an entitlement is within reach emerged in the same week that cherie booth called for improved rights for parttime workers and more job sharing as a part of a drive towards more familyfriendly employment however while pressure groups and unions would welcome the reform employers will be concerned about the burden on business government sources say the most resistance is likely to come from mediumsized companies because many larger firms already have the scope to offer parttime deals the smallest organisations are regarded as flexible ministers and sources at the crossdepartmental womens unit believe that change is necessary if the governments commitment to address the worklife balance is to have meaning one source said we know that while the economy is strong it is a sellers market and employers are having to offer flexible working arrangements as part of recruitment packages to recruit the right people but if things get tighter those advantages could be taken away again and women could be left with no negotiating power womens ministers point out that deprived of the chance to return to work parttime many women particularly in low paid jobs opt not to go back to work this mr byers is being lobbied on the issue as the regulations for implementing the european directive on parttime work are finalised no timescale has been set for his review of maternity pay and rights text: cherie booth dropped a broad hint last night that she would like her husband tony blair to take a break from running the country and spend some time with her and their baby after it is born in may she told lawyers and academics at kings college london i am pleased to report that in the prime minister of finland took advantage of his right to parental leave he has done it again recently i for one am promoting the widespread adoption of his fine example delivering a lecture titled the paneuropean vision of labour law in the year she said it is time that men started to challenge the assumptions in the workplace that the nurturing of children has nothing to do with them our children need their male role models as well as their female ones if they are to grow up into wellrounded wellbalanced individuals criticising the long hours workplace culture she called on employers to help their employees particularly women strike a balance between work and family she said the lives of working women were made difficult and sometimes intolerable by the employment environment and its inherent discrimination one form of discrimination she said was the daytoday struggle faced by women as they attempted to balance their paid working lives and their unpaid working lives the second she said was the discrimination which is loudly and clearly spelled out by the pay gap the work environment with rigid working hours inflexible leave patterns long hours and intolerance of career breaks discriminated against women with families but the legal system had not developed quickly enough to deal with this type of discrimination said ms booth a qc specialising in employment law but she believed this would change because employers would need to employ and retain women in the workplace the success of the economy would depend on the skills that women excel at project management knowledge development sharing interpersonal skills and high standards of customer service progress had been helped by legal rights coming mainly from europe but happily grasped with more vigour by the present government these included improved maternity rights parental leave emergency leave for family crises and equal rights for parttime workers but parttime rights could be a doubleedged sword she said the low status and low pay helped perpetuate the pay gap between men and women who made up of parttimers she called for a statutory right for women to return to work part time after having a baby unless the employer could justify requiring her to work full time this would leave employers less vulnerable to claims and large payouts under the sex discrimination act there is no protection from discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation under english law but ms booth predicted that the human rights act and powers in the treaty of amsterdam would give gays greater rights by she concluded the partial and if im being incredibly optimistic total closure of the pay gap will be achievable by if we all tackle it with the vigour that this form of outright discrimination against women warrants i hope that we will see in for example john a gay man having protection against discrimination on the grounds of his sexual orientation and mary a yearold working mum earning the same percentage on a parttime basis as john and having the right to request such parttime work from a fulltime position without fear of losing her job

text: things are coming together for families at last we are waking up to the facts of social life that we are all connected to each other business depends on people and people depend on business if it takes terms like human capital and family business to persuade the hardheaded that investing in families is the only sensible course to take in social policy thats ok now is the time for the chancellor to reach into his pocket and invest in families in his budget next week he could do much to put substance behind the governments commitment to help families with young children he could increase the flat rate maternity pay from to per week extend the period of entitlement from to weeks and increase the number of weeks paid at of salary from the current six weeks to weeks allowing more mothers to stay at home in the early weeks if they want to he could also raise the child benefit payment in the first year all of these will have a different effect and help different types of family apart from the wealthy all families have a stake in this but there are principles poor families must be helped too this is why we are urging the chancellor to increase the sure start maternity grant to to provide realistic support for mothers and babies in deprived areas there are hard decisions to take about who receives the money since children benefit more from mothers money than from fathers at least we are seriously thinking about worklife balance giving people time to be a family we have the right to parental leave when the need is there though not the means to make it a reality we are finding ways to improve teaching in schools about relationships we even recognise that the same skills are needed in the school home work place and on the streets if we are to be able to lead the good life together all the evidence from research shows that it is the quality of relationships whether in the home or in child care that raises children well its about promoting a culture of decency but caring has always been harder to do on an empty stomach or with worries about how to manage this is especially so now in the presence of conspicuous wealth and fame families need to be supported with money as well as words and the money is there we cannot remind ourselves enough that one in three children in the uk lives in poverty and that it greatly affects life chances we hear that many mothers who want to stay at home longer to care for their babies cant because they fear they will lose their jobs or the mortgage makes it impossible to think of giving up work we know that in the early months of their lives babies are highly sensitive and we have to make it possible for families to provide the best quality of care at that time however they can manage it this is good for baby and good for mother and father shame on you parliament for going wobbly at the sight of mothers breastfeeding is it too much of a reminder that all you big grownup powerful people who make laws were babies once a few measures could transform these early months for families and for children an investment to grow our human capital but the devil is in the detail what kind of investment to whom when for how long and who pays and the detail is certainly devilish as anybody who has tried to explain working families tax credit can confirm we have spent too long putting up with a piecemeal system of family benefits bits tacked on to bits let us get some joined up work to transform the mess into a transparent understandable system where people can work out their likely entitlements without needing armies of benefits advisers to make sense of it given the complexity that is a longerterm goal and it should be in every partys manifesto but what about now much as it is tempting to say go back to the drawing board over the whole system and set up another review of which this government has done so many we need something now parental leave must be paid this would be a direct contribution to poorer families uk research has shown they are least likely to be able to take leave families must get extra resources to make these early vital months easier it is simply crazy to have mothers unwilling and sad at work if they would rather be caring for their babies at home and for the cash conscious it is the cheapest way lots of families just cannot avoid debt with mothers at home and want the parttime solution the government should make it a right

text: vicky diaz is a yearold mother of five a former teacher in the philippines she migrated to the united states to work as a housekeeper and nanny to the twoyearold son of a wealthy family in beverly hills los angeles even now my children are trying to convince me to go home she says they werent angry when i left because they were still very young my husband couldnt get angry either because he knew this was the only way i could help him raise our children i send them money every month the beverly hills family pays vicky a week vicky pays her own familys livein domestic worker back in the philippines a week but living in this global care chain is not easy on vicky and her family im paid well but im sinking in work even while i am ironing the clothes they can still call you to the kitchen to wash the plates it is also very depressing away from my children the only thing i can do is give all my love to tommy the twoyearold american child paradoxically vicky got her job by telling her prospective employer she had experience raising children they asked me if i knew how to take care of a child and i told them i did because i had five of my own global capitalism affects whatever it touches and it touches everything global care chains are usually made up of women most start in a poor country and end in a rich one the chain vicky diaz finds herself in is an increasingly common one an older daughter from a poor family cares for her siblings while her mother works as a nanny caring for the children of a migrating nanny who cares for the child of a family in a rich country however long the care chain is everyone in it tends to focus on the link closest to them from time to time vicky may feel keenly the link between her love for the children she is paid to care for and love of her own children whom she pays another to nurture but her american employers are more likely to see this love as natural individual uncircumscribed by context vicky is a loving person they might say vicky loves tommy but can love be displaced from vicky diazs son alfredo in the philippines on to tommy the son of her employers in los angeles and should we worry that the direction of displacement is upwards in privilege and power are firstworld countries importing maternal love as they have imported copper zinc and gold from thirdworld countries in the past love is not simply a resource that can be taken from one person and given to another but nor is it entirely unlike a resource is time spent with the firstworld child taken from a child further down the care chain is the beverly hills toddler getting surplus love just as the mine owner gets surplus value from the worker digging for gold the idea is unwelcome both to vicky diaz who wants a firstworld job and to her wellmeaning employers who need someone to give loving care to their child each person along the chain feels he or she is doing the right thing for good reasons but transfer of care takes its toll both on the child left behind and on the mother when i saw my children said one filipino nanny weeping i thought oh children do grow up even without their mother i left my youngest when she was only five she was nine when i saw her again but she still wanted me to carry her that hurt me because it showed me that my children missed out a lot sometimes the toll it takes is overwhelming as one filipino nanny said the first two years i felt i was going crazy i would catch myself thinking about my baby every moment every second of the day when i receive a letter from my children i cannot sleep i cry given the depth of this unhappiness one might imagine care chains are a minimal part of the global show but this is not the case since the early s for example of migrants from the philippines have been women and next to electronic manufacturing their remittances make up the countrys major source of foreign currency recent improvements in the economy have not reduced female emigration rather it continues to increase in addition migrants are not drawn from the poorest classes in one study of migrant filipino domestic workers over half the nannies were graduates and most were married mothers in their s money provides a powerful incentive to work and the yawning global wage gap provides a powerful incentive to move migration is simply a ticket to a better life just as global capitalism helps create a thirdworld supply of mothering so it creates a firstworld demand for it at the firstworld end there has been a huge rise in the number of women in paid work from of mothers of children aged six and under in to today indeed american women now make up of the us labour force of mothers of children aged and under now work as do of mothers of children aged six and under in addition working hours have been rising and a lot of american grandmothers who might otherwise have looked after a workers children now do paid work themselves thus at the firstworld end of care chains we find working parents who are grateful to find a good nanny and able to pay more than the nanny could earn in her native country firstworld women who hire nannies are themselves caught in a male career pattern that has proved surprisingly resistant to change women have joined the law academia medicine business professions still organised for men with families who are free of family responsibilities today men take on much more of the childcare and housework but they still base their identity on demanding careers hence the resistance to sharing care at home and the search for care further down the global chain among these firstworld mothers are those who give their emotional labour in turn to companies that hold themselves out as a family researching a leading multinational company i call amerco i discovered a disproportionate number of women employed in the human side public relations marketing human resources it was often the soft touch of women that made amerco seem like a family to other workers among the ultimate beneficiaries of various care chains we thus find multinational companies given the existence of this global care chain and given the chains growing scope it is worth asking how we are to respond i can think of three ways to see care chains through the eyes of the primordialist the sunshine modernist and the critical modernist to the primordialist the right thing would be for each of us to take care of only our own family in our own nation to such a person the existence of care chains seems wrong because such care is usually done by women primordialists often also believe that women should stay at home to provide this care but for the sunshine modernist care chains are an inevitable part of globalisation which is itself uncritically accepted as good if a supply of labour meets demand the sunshine modernist is satisfied the issue of inequality of access to care disappears the critical modernist has a global sense of ethics if she goes out to buy nike shoes she is concerned to learn how low the wage and how long the hours were for the thirdworld factory worker making them she applies the same moral concern to care so she cares about the welfare of the filipino child back home and sees globalisation as a very mixed blessing it brings new opportunities and the nannys access to good wages is one but also new problems including costs we have hardly begun to understand though it is not always the case the poor maids child may be getting less motherly care than the firstworld child we neednt lapse into primordialism to sense that something may be amiss and to search for solutions one approach is to try to reduce incentives to migrate by addressing the causes of the migrants economic desperation another would be to raise the value of caring work such that whoever did it got more credit as well as money for it and care wasnt such a pass on job the value of the labour of raising a child always low relative to the value of other kinds of labour has under the impact of globalisation sunk lower still the declining value of childcare can be compared with the declining value of basic food crops relative to manufactured goods on the international market though clearly more necessary to life crops such as wheat rice or cocoa fetch low and declining prices while those of manufactured goods continue to soar just as the market price of primary produce keeps the third world low in the community of nations so the low market value of care keeps the status of the women who do it and by association all women low a final basic solution would be to involve fathers in caring for their children if fathers shared care it would spread laterally instead of being passed down a social class ladder according to the international labour organisation half of the worlds women between and are in paid work since the rate of increase has skyrocketed in the us and has been high in scandinavia and the uk if we want developed societies with women doctors political leaders teachers and computer programmers we will need qualified people to help care for their children and there is no reason why every society should not enjoy such loving paid childcare it may even be true that vicky diaz is the person to provide it at the same time critical modernists would be wise to extend their concern to the possible hidden losers in the care chain for these days the personal is global this is an extract from an essay which appears in on the edge living with global capitalism edited by will hutton and anthony giddens published by jonathan cape on march price to order a copy at the special price of plus p uk pampp freephone guardian cultureshop on

text: the suggestion that feminine qualities are better suited to modern management is well known but last week research from the industrial society appeared to give the idea real substance the results of a survey published by the society showed that the best leadership came from women the under s and those working in the public sector the study the result of three years research asked workers to list the qualities they believed were important in management and rate these against the skills of their current bosses things are not quite that simple of course if women managers seem to have the qualities that workers admire trustworthiness delegation and the ability to set out clear goals it does not necessarily follow that the qualities are intrinsically feminine were not saying men cant do this says debra allcock head of campaigning at the industrial society by the same token the emphasis on youth can appear misleading the fact that best management practice was seen to be concentrated among the under s is probably as significant as the anomaly that the best management practice was found in scotland it is most likely to be related to the fact that more open leadership was generally found lower down the corporate hierarchy among teamleaders and supervisers than among senior management in fact when rated on trust managers under came out with the lowest rating while those over achieved the best it is clearly not a question of age alone but of the qualities themselves tempered by experience the command and control style of management is gradually giving way to a more flexible and collegiate and arguably more feminine approach and managers of all ages must learn to adapt whether they are or they must accept that they have a limited shelflife if they dont says allcock

text: as employee empowerment develops apace it seems beyond belief that anyone would confident enough to blackmail a colleague or client yet that is exactly what carol winstonchurchill who is a barrister attempted with an american investment banker last week at the old bailey winstonchurchill pleaded guilty to threatening to tell david browns manhattan employers bear stern amp company that he was gay after his plans to buy a house in jamaica in fell through brown had already given winstonchurchill for conveyancing fees she refused to return it when the deal was called off when his lawyers began proceedings to recover the money she threatened him the banker who has since died was not in fact homosexual he went straight to the police however winstonchurchill apparently believed that she could exploit the stigma associated with homosexuality at the time but that was nearly years ago could such a thing happen in the modern workplace the last thing yearold david coppola expected when he joined the london office of a multinational bank was a succession of professional snubs and a salary just over half that of younger less qualified colleagues as a senior consultant in commercial banking coppola had been targeted as a fasttrack highflier a successful and wellliked key player in his field his scheduled progression through the initial twoyear tenure was guaranteed or so he thought after five years with the company he has been promoted only once and achieved a salary package far from commensurate with his position the reason he alleges is his sexuality in the first year the fact that im gay came out gradually over postwork drinks i never made a big deal of it and eventually most of my colleagues sussed it anyway he says at this stage coppola reckons he should be at the peak of his career his peers are on around one and half times his present salary and are rising through the ranks his career appears to have reached a standstill glass ceiling is a term usually applied to women who are unable to achieve senior directorial positions as a result of gender prejudice within the workplace until now the gay glass ceiling has not come under close scrutiny by the national lesbian and gay campaigning organisations research and monitoring of individual cases is minimal in part because it is difficult to quantify in part because the position of the individu als affected has not been publicised we do get approached by people who believe their sexuality combined with other peoples prejudice makes promotion problematic says phil greasley who is a campaigner with the lobby group lager lesbian and gay equal rights we try to do as much for them as we can but its difficult to prove an employer is free to choose who to promote and who not to and its easy to assess people so that they dont reach a level for promotion sometimes attitude or approach are mentioned in a negative way its the small details that add up to important evidence though and greasley thinks if it can be shown that a person has been unfairly treated its not always necessary to prove that sexuality is the reason coppola has a briefcase full of details he believes he has been regularly excluded from significant meetings business trips and conferences and kept isolated and uninformed coppola is not alone in his complaint in other instances too a gay glass ceiling appears to be firmly if unofficially lodged in company structure paul mcbride is a human resources manager working for a city council around the predominant male managers mcbrides honesty about his sexuality makes people twitchy he came out to his colleagues six months after joining the council eight years later he has reservations about having done it because of the still largely blokish office culture im not the kind of person who talks about their sex life a lot but i have found it in my interest to play it down the further up the organisation i go the more i find myself spending time with women at the same level because we have quite a lot of common experiences we dont get invited to the pub or to play golf for some the absence of a family causes problems the corporate publication management today cites sir bob reid deputy governor of the bank of scotland who believes that anyone gay or straight who lacks a solid family backdrop is suspicious the whole thing about life is that you get into trouble because you dont have a wide breadth of experience you have to be suspicious of people who dont have children jumping on their sofas at home they dont know about real life mcbride is not surprised by reids remarks there are still very strong male networks and although on the surface it doesnt look like thats whats going on the higher up you get most business goes on outside the office and you dont get invited you just dont find out in dr nicholas priestley a clinical neuropsychologist was made clinical director of a private clinic in bury as one of the countrys leading expert witnesses in headinjury litigation and one of the most senior doctors in his field priestley was regarded as the only suitable candidate thrilled to be appointed he had no idea that three years later he would be embroiled in an industrial tribunal with his employers westminster healthcare over sex discrimination and constructive dismissal priestley alleges that management and colleagues taunted him relentlessly about his sex uality and the integrity of his character in the corridor colleagues would call me sick and perverted priestley claims they simply could not treat a gay man as an equal in two years he alleges he was ostracised and undermined by his coworkers and asked on several occasions to change his personality which he read as sexuality priestley made more than written and verbal complaints to his employers about his treatment in june priestley felt he had no option but to hand in his resignation priestleys claims are denied by his employers who say that there was no discrimination and that priestley resigned for his own reasons priestley hoped to win a moral victory at industrial tribunal but claims the day hearing was unfair he claims that at one point he was asked when taking the oath how he could swear on the bible given that he was gay priestley felt forced to abandon his case and a complaint has been made to the lord chancellors department about the conduct of the tribunal priestley is now a national health service consultant neuropsychologist at a hospital in widnes since his story has become public with the backing of stonewall the gay rights group the trades union congress and now liberty priestley has received overwhelming support from a number of labour mps who are keen to see his case used to bring about a change in the law on employment rights for lesbians and gay men speaking in the house of commons on december priestleys mp david chaytorm said if dr priestley had been a woman had had a disability of some kind or had been a member of an ethnic minority he would have had recourse to the law earlier there is clearly a case for building discrimination on the grounds of sexuality into antidiscrimination legislation priestley says that his case has acted as a catalyst for the introduction of a voluntary code of practice in the public sector in the near future which although not directly effective in the private sphere would make it more difficult for employers to discriminate in the workplace campaigners believe its a start though not much to shout about and nicholas priestley concludes a statutory code of conduct must be implemented good employers are already implementing such policy its the bad ones who must be forced to change such a move would finally change a culture which can sustain blackmail and everyday acts of prejudice as well as the glass ceiling amp jane czyzselska writes regularly on gay rights at work for attitude magazine some names have been changed to protect the individuals concerned

text: do children suffer when their mothers work or do they thrive hardly a month goes by without a study establishing beyond doubt that children who are put into nurseries by their working mothers a grow up to be emotional and educational cripples or b are the luckiest most talented and resilient creatures who ever lived its an eitheror debate that has had a pernicious effect whatever parents decide to stay at home fulltime to work parttime fulltime or overtime to put their children into nurseries occasionally or all day long or use no childcare at all one group of experts will say it is the wrong choice but maybe both sides of the debate have got it wrong according to ellen galinsky of the new yorkbased families and work institute maternal employment is not the alldetermining factor we thought it was what counts is not if a mother works but how she works and how a father works counts as much if mothers and fathers are stressed at work they will bring their work home with them but as common sense suggests and research can now confirm if they are in happier jobs in which they enjoy a degree of autonomy they have more energy for their children when they get home and their children are the better for it the evidence from a large study by the us national institute of child health and human development is that children do best when their mothers can choose whether to work or stay at home having been able to make a positive choice about the arrangements that best suit them and their families they are miraculously more effective as parents the study has also found that while good childcare can have a small positive effect on childrens cognitive development the quality of family life continues to be the most important influence on a childs development family life does not just depend on love but also on money the biggest single risk factor when assessing a childs chances in life turns out to be poverty common sense suggests all this but why has it taken so long to find its way into serious research tony munton of the institute of education says john bowlby is to blame dr bowlby is the originator of attachment theory which grew out of work he did after world war ii with children in institutional care having found their emotional and intellectual development was impaired he concluded that a childs development is contingent on exclusive maternal care that maternal separation from the child disrupts the attachment process and that therefore mothers with young children should not work policymakers trying to find jobs for men returning from the war took to the theory with enthusiasm women had taken over many jobs and if they did not now step out of them the country would have a problem according to dr munton attachment theory gave a theoretical justification to the argument that mothers should not work it influenced policy makers the world over in the world health organistion went so far as to say that the use of day nurseries would cause permanent damage to the emotional health of a future generation attachment theory has continued to influence policy on mothers working though it has had a shakier career in the academic world bowlbys research was about children in residential care studies of children in daycare have not uncovered the same problems munton notes that bowlbys ideas on the need for the mother to be exclusive carer were not confirmed by a review of nonindustrial societies where only five had mothers as exclusive carers according to michael rutter of the institute of psychiatry in london children can cope well with several adults caring for them provided it is the same adults over time and provided that the individuals with whom they have secure relationships are available at times when they are tired distressed or facing challenging circumstances these secure relationships do not need to take place inside a home there is no reason why a child could not also enjoy the same benefits when in the care of trained professionals even so it would be silly even dangerous to deduce from this that children of working mothers thrive or that childcare is good for children its only good if it is well good but knowing that does not answer the important question what sort of life do we want for our children at home and outside during their early years how much time do we want them to spend outside the home how much time do we want to spend with them when should they start formal education now that research has shown how important informal play is should we put kids into school at four these are the sorts of practical forwardlooking questions that we need to be asking if we are going to get childcare right they are urgent questions says anne longfield of the kids clubs network more than half of mothers whose youngest child is under five are now economically active and per cent of mothers whose youngest child is between five and now work most have no choice it is that or poverty quality is important to all working parents when making childcare arrangements but in practice they are seldom in a position to insist on it demand far exceeds supply only per cent of undereights have access to a registered childcare place fewer than per cent of year olds have access to outofschool childcare or holiday playschemes and yet per cent of working families use childcare twothirds of children under five spend time in the care of adults who are not their parents most of these adults are not trained professionals but relatives neighbours and unregistered untrained childminders most families have no choice but to resort to informal care arrangements with private nurseries charging roughly the same as private schools most families would not be able to afford formal childcare even if it were available so they make do with the resources they have to hand while informal care can be a good thing as in the case of a doting grandmother it can also mean leaving children with people who have little understanding of children and may even be a danger to them but much of the registered care on offer is also poor no working parent can breathe easily until all childcare workers are held to consistent and enforceable standards the clunkily named national childcare strategy is a vast initiative that aims to create childcare places for up to a million children new outofschool clubs and new playworker and childcare jobs it hopes to offer one million children safe and enjoying learning opportunities support one million parents to work or train and help a quarter of a million parents move off benefits its mantra is quality quality quality get childcare right and well see less delinquency in adolescence and happier higher achieving adults and all of society will benefit the key concept is continuity at present says dr munton a child will have been through as many as seven or eight different child care arrangements by the age of five and thats not good childcare services should be designed so that children dont lose touch with the carers they love and trust on a routine basis this is one of the reasons why in the centres of excellence that the government has set up to date the aim is to provide childcare from birth to age but even the highest quality childcare services are worthless unless they fit in with the way we work they have to suit shift workers and shortterm contract workers and parents who work long or antisocial hours not just the lucky few who are still in stable to jobs so to get childcare right you have to push for serious changes in the work world too according to munton the national childcare strategy is the most radical piece of legislation weve seen in this country since the formation of the welfare state but the majority of people dont know about it what we need according to munton and galinsky and their fellow campaigners is to throw out the old debate and begin a new one the first challenge is to make sure children get the best possible environments wherever they are the second challenge is to make sure that working parents have access to high quality services they can afford the third is to make sure that childcare is not compulsory it is important says lucy daniels associate director of the worklife research centre that parents do not allow themselves to be turned into wage slaves there is always the danger that a vast supply of high quality childcare might give parents less leverage when arguing for flexible familyfriendly work patterns but parents and children of all ages need family time and parents with very young children should be able to stay at home with their children for extended periods without having to suffer the severe economic setbacks they do today the national childcare strategy needs to go hand in hand with some sort of national workplace strategy the idea that childcare is not just a private responsibility but also a social one has become a minority view the majority think mothers who involve others in the care of their children are mothers who are not doing their job and that government should not spend money to let them off the hook according to daniels the main challenge is to make the case that good childcare like good health and education is good for society this sounds like yet another piece of common sense caring for children means caring for the next generation it is in everyones interest we do the job well

familyfriendly every parent will be offered up to paid weeks off work at an estimated cost of m a year in a move designed to be a centrepiece of labours policy on the family in the manifesto for the next general election the trade and industry secretary stephen byers is backing proposals drawn up by the labour mp ruth kelly on behalf of the strong labour parliamentary womens group mr byers who is in charge of government policy on maternity pay and parental leave said this is a significant piece of work which will inform our consideration of this important area government ministers are to start lobbying business to persuade them that paid parental leave will be good for firms leading to a more contented workforce and helping them attract and keep key staff while ministers are keen to maintain business support for the government they believe the scheme would help the government appeal to women voters who backed tony blair in the election but have since started to have second text: cherie booth and madonna two women who were by no means universally popular a few months ago have succeeded in turning themselves into national heroines by becoming pregnant in their forties while it is generally frowned upon to reproduce in your teens and considered sensible to get on with it in your twenties and thirties there seems to be something reckless but charming about a woman in her forties making the sacrifices necessary for parenthood but longed for or unexpected the reality of having children in ones forties can be tough apart from the health risks to mother and child it can play havoc with carefully laid plans career women such as cherie booth are probably getting to the peak of their earning power and may be unwilling to take a career break or to cut back on working days moreover when booths youngest child reaches the age when he or she may want to go on to university its mother will be an age by which many people hope to have retired setting these two expectant mothers aside as their wealth makes them untypical anyone contemplating parenthood perhaps for the first time in her forties will face complicated financial choices it may seem a prosaic consideration but it is worth bearing in mind that a career break can wreck your pension planning someone who takes off the average of six and a half years to raise a child can retire on a third less than colleagues who do not if you do take a break you should restart and increase your contributions as soon as you can the alternative is bleak a recent survey by lloyds bank showed that more than half british women and most of those who take career breaks are women due to retire in will receive pensions below the poverty line currently you are not allowed to contribute to a pension either a company or personal one unless you are in paid employment company pension schemes usually treat statutory maternity leave as pensionable service and expect you to continue your contributions you can either save a percentage of your statutory maternity pay and pay less into your pension or you can carry on with the normal contributions if you can afford it if you take longer leave than the statutory minimum you are not allowed to continue your contributions the introduction of the stakeholder pension in april next year offers hope to thousands of people who are taking a career break not only will the scheme be cheap the maximum charge is capped at per cent per year but you will be able to put money aside for your retirement regardless of whether you are in paid employment and you will still qualify for tax contributions on your highest rate state support for women who stop work to have a baby is not generous statutory maternity pay is only a week oneoff sure start grants are available for less welloff families which with a household income of up to may be eligible for the working families tax credit but the qualifying rules are complicated british parents are also lumbered with some of the highest childcare bills in europe a late addition to the family of a working woman may mean a return to paying a nannys salary or nursery or childminders fees just as older children have begun to fend for themselves parents who have spare cash are often keen to save for their childrens future this may be especially true if they are concerned that they will no longer be earning as the child enters adulthood banks and building societies offer competitive savings accounts for children rates can be more than per cent and your children can usually register to have the interest paid before tax you can also invest in the stock market on behalf of your children but beware the inland revenue rules governing the amount that parents can give to their children friends and other relatives are not similarly hampered you may even wish to consider buying a stakeholder pension for your child as surprisingly there is no age limit on who can take one out donna bradshaw of fiona price and partners says that when she has pointed out to parents that the money will be locked up until their child turns their reaction has not been disappointment but delight twin reasons to rethink sue douse who turns in june had planned to have more children since the birth of her son christopher nine years ago unfortunately she had difficulty conceiving and turned to fertility treatment the happy result of this was the birth four and a half months ago of twin daughters annabelle and samantha but however thoroughly thought through the arrival of children has had a major impact on her finances sue from surrey needs to travel a lot in her work as a senior investment consultant she has recently returned to her job fulltime and realised that she needed a topclass nanny to take care of her three children while she worked to do this the nanny has to be really wonderful she says such nannies do not come cheap also her new nanny has her hands full with the children meaning that sue has had to take on a cleaner on the plus side having more children has made her give a bit more time to focusing on her familys finances rather than just other peoples i never seemed to have time to sit down and think about it before she says some of her precious maternity leave was taken up with her financial reorganisation including remortgaging the family home so that we have a comfortable retirement as well as providing for the children

out to bring up children the logic in favour of reform is clear as it stands the european union directive introduced last december means that all parents now have the right to a minimum of weeks leave without pay which may be taken at any time until each child is five years old but lets face it its an expensive option one that many mums and dads can only dream of says dianah worman adviser to the institute of personnel and development consequently lowpaid parents have to sit in envy watching their wealthier colleagues take advantage of a law that they cannot she points to a law passed by the clinton administration in giving parents in the us similar rights the law was certainly popular but takeup among families on low incomes was vastly reduced paid parental leave must be the answer right wrong argues ruth lea head of policy at the institute of directors iod current maternity rights already make of iod members think twice about hiring young women and the introduction of paid parental leave would compound this she says its not a matter of breaking the sex discrimination act its simply a matter of running your firm to survive our members have to run businesses in a tough competitive usually for family commitments in fact last week many small businesses opposed the governments announcement claiming they would rather choose to develop their own policies on parental leave nearly saying that parents shouldnt get free child care just that any arrangements should be developed to meet the needs of both the individual employer and employee says worman the same goes for employees
