text: the world welcomed baby leo but few as warmly as those pressing the government to revise its dickensian policies on worklife balance by chance the blair baby has arrived right into the middle of national childcare week and its organisers could hardly contain their grins in westminster junior ministers and mps all of them women were nudging one another gloating and beaming hello leo in this tiny personage is now vested high hopes of radical change there is a groundswell of anger about our overworking brutalising long hours culture and labours deliberate weakening of every eu directive aimed at making life bearable for working families not so much new labour as hard labour now in the air there hovers the inescapable image of the infant leo its not that anyone thinks the prime minister has gone soft perish the thought only last week he went out of his way to promise the cbi that there would be ever less regulation on employers boasting that britains employers are even more lightly regulated than in the united states his government is still trying to deny parental leave to the great majority of parents even as his wife acted in court for the tuc yesterday disgracefully the government effectively got its way although the judges said the tuc case was likely to prevail they still sent the case off to brussels where it may take two years by which time many of the disputed parents will have lost their rights as their children will be over five years old a good example of justice delayed being justice denied but whatever his father thinks leos presence will not let the issue to go away look at that charming picture of the prime minister taking his parental leave lolling on a sofa in his casual clothes cooing happily to his baby while his government prevents most other parents doing likewise it just doesnt look good its another worrying example of how downing street is losing its political touch obstinacy on parental leave is needless folly when the case could have been gracefully withdrawn with a sincere promise to think again why do they bother fighting it so hard when this unpaid parental leave will be taken by very few only parents in countries where the leave is paid can afford to take it little leo will raise other questions for example when will his mother go back to work will it be as soon as paid maternity is over at weeks like most women have to far too soon or will it be after the other weeks unpaid which only a few welloff women can afford to take also too soon then comes childcare most families dont and cant afford to pay for invited in that moving part of last years prime ministerial party conference speech there is no more powerful symbol of our politics than the experience of being on a maternity ward seeing two babies no job no family to support her sadder still no one to share the joy and triumph of the new baby a father nowhere to be seen the second child returns to a prosperous home grandparents desperate to share the caring and a father with a decent income and an even larger sense of pride he called for strong families cherished by strong communities and although he was talking mainly about this fine promise to abolish child poverty in years it takes good familyfriendly policies to support strong families today a mori poll for national childcare week asks mothers what hinders them returning to work three quarters of parents polled said it as lack of affordable childcare employers have done virtually nothing to help only have workplace nurseries only offer help with costs it helps explain why not nearly enough mothers invited to join the new deal for lone parents have taken up the offer the main point of childcare tax credits was to try to entice the single mothers living on benefits opportunities fund has done well in spreading afterschool and holiday clubs around the country but for the under threes there is very little a network of stateoftheart young childrens centres as found in much of europe is still an age away we await julys spending review margaret jay margaret hodge yvette cooper tessa jowell and many women backbenchers led by harriet harman are now arguing fiercely for more childcare and for a radical new focus on the whole worklife agenda stephen byers is one of those responsible for the serious error this government made in siding with whingeing small employers against the clear distress of an overworked nation it was he who tried to whittle parttime workers rights down to almost nothing but now even he has seen the light and is bidding strongly text: more than million working parents excluded from the governments new parental leave scheme face a long wait to learn the outcome of a legal challenge launched on their behalf by the tuc the high court today referred the case to the european court of justice for a ruling on the meaning of part of the european parental leave directive and agreement on which the scheme is based which could take up to two years the high court refused the tucs plea for an order that in the meantime the excluded parents could take leave even though they might eventually lose the case but lord bingham the lord chief justice and mr justice morison urged the european court to deal with the case as a matter of urgency they said that if as we think trade and industry secretary stephen byers may have acted unlawfully in the way he introduced the scheme the sooner this is made clear the better the tucs argument that the government broke european law by excluding million employees from the right to take unpaid parental leave was presented last week by cherie booth qc in her last court appearance before the birth of her son leo under the parental leave regulations introduced on december last year parents of children born or adopted on or after that date are entitled to weeks leave spread over the years up to a childs fifth birthday the prime ministers wife seeking judicial review in a case against mr byers contended that the cutoff date wrongly shut out parents of children under five born before december today the tuc was given leave to appeal against the judges refusal to grant an interim order allowing the parents to take leave while europe decides the court heard that if the european court took two years to make a ruling around one million of the parents would have lost their leave entitlement forever because their children would by then be more than five tuc general secretary john monks claimed a clear moral victory after todays judgement ministers should now extend parental leave to the nearly million working parents who have missed out without the need for a lengthy european court case he said fighting what looks like a doomed case in the european court simply to delay parental leave for those parents with children born before the december deadline sends all the wrong signals from a government that says it wants a better worklife balance he said it is sad to see the uk government take such a familyunfriendly position a spokesman for the department of trade and industry said it is right that this question should be resolved in european courts this is what we requested useful links ecj the tuc related story april new deal for parents

significance from choice of nappy we already know their preference is for terry towelling rather than easy but landfillclogging disposables to childcare in a spindoctored world where the personal is political and vice versa such details will be headline news reported and chewed over by a string of columnists in more depth than britains dilemmas over euro entry below we detail some of the critical decisions facing the blairs like any parents over the first months and gauge the significance of their preferences in buggies and babyfood for a fickle electorate breastfeeding always a hot topic and now more political than ever due to the row over breastfeeding in the house of commons despite requests from mps nursing newborns the speakers office has banned the taking of refreshment in committee rooms a new government breast is best campaign launched only days before mrs blair entered the labour ward is intended to boost uk breastfeeding rates from among the lowest in europe and the department of health would doubtless welcome such a highprofile example on the basis of current statistics she is almost certain to nurse assuming all goes smoothly figures show that middleclass educated older mothers are far more likely than their less welloff counterparts to prefer breast to bottle however if the lure of a return to the courtroom proves irresistible within weeks she may choose to switch wholly or partly to formula potentially incurring the wrath of the breastisbest lobby the choice of brand is a minefield an ethical foreign policy would not approve of manufacturers who foist formula on poor women in developing countries fathers role tony blair has already encountered the politics of paternity leave a right which does not exist in the uk though a new entitlement to unpaid parental leave has just been introduced and has opted for a typically new labour third way to the disappointment of campaigners for better balance between home and work he will not take time off but hop up and down the downing street staircase between his no office and the first familys appartment above no but while the prime minister clearly did not feel he could be as radical as finnish prime minister paavo lipponen who took a weeks leave on the birth of his baby last february he is known to value greatly the time spent with his older children and is certain to be an involved father visitors to chequers report that the blair children and their father can often be found playing football in the gardens and mr blair frequently refers in interviews to cherie and the kids a key influence on the prime minister is likely to be the memory of the severe stroke which hit his own father leo at just the illness though devastating meant he benefited by seeing much more of the once workaholic barrister mr blair has said however as prime minister the battle for worklife balance is one he is unlikely to win if the polls dip for labour critics will accuse him of devoting too much time to fatherhood while leaving childcare duties to mrs blair and the nanny will mean bowing to the forces of conservatism he claims to despise childcare another contentious issue mrs blair has already disclosed that initially at least she will spurn paid help in favour of her mother gale booth who will move into the downing street flat in doing so she will buck the trend among professional parents only of whom rely on relatives to look after their children compared with of lowerincome groups later on the blairs may well turn to a livein nanny which would highlight the fact that for the vast majority of parents finding good childcare is costly with neither tax relief nor employer incentives the blairs will also have to address the problem of isolation for the downing street baby particularly since friends their own age are likely to have children much older than the new arrival if they choose a toddler group nursery or playgroup it will have to be a public or voluntarysector risky for tony blair is the question of gm food the pm has indicated that he is happy to eat gm himself but the spectacle of former tory minister john gummer stuffing a burger down his daughters at home in line with the governments promotion of familyfriendly working publicity the blairs have always made much of shielding their children and family life from the public eye and insist they want to continue that policy with leo downing street has promised one photo session after which he will disappear behind the security gates of downing street emerging for the cameras only for the familys traditional tuscan summer holiday snap with a general election possibly under a year away however the temptation to wheel out the new arrival from time to time could prove too great leading to a curious synchronicity between the little ones outings and william hagues keynote speeches the blairs will have to be careful though any hint of exploitation and the strategy will backfire with the text: leading businesswomen launched a scathing attack on the governments record on maternity rights last night claiming that britain is the worst place in europe to be a working mother the condemnation came as female executives from overseas on an advanced management course at the london business school this month heard with astonishment of the poor leave arrangements and employer attitudes that highflying british women face julia martin a fund manager drew gasps from her foreign counterparts when she said she could take just weeks maternity leave after the birth of her second baby it took me three months just to get used to being a mum said randi birkeland mother to four children and a vice president of norways hydro supply network in norway as in denmark and sweden women are entitled to a years paid leave and for a year after they return to work they are entitled to work shorter hours while they continue breastfeeding margareta le calv general manager of swedish communications giant telenordia has recently been promoted she is six months pregnant and expects to make the most of her countrys generous parental rights these include an incentive to fathers to take days paid leave after the birth and then a further four weeks during the childs first year men are also entitled to take some of their partners entitlement meaning the total leave can be shared martin said some of the blokes say dont you have to rush home for the children they assume its the woman who will rush home they think women wont want to travel away from home maryann stephenson director of the fawcett society which campaigns for equality between women and men said this is not limited to small companies the majority of male directors of ftse companies are married with children the majority of the few women directors are single without children yet when we look abroad it is obvious that a company can still be efficient and make lots of money if it looks after its female employees the average woman in britain has just eight weeks maternity leave on full pay compared to the european average of weeks stephenson said women in this country have come to accept a poor deal as normal they were allowed into the workplace so long as they worked like men but the normal working model here is based on just half the population the whole issue of long hours the attitude to jobsharing and parttime working for men and women needs to be addressed julia mellor head of the equal opportunities commission said employers as well as employees have much to gain from better parental leave and maternity arrangements many are concerned about the number of people leaving good jobs because they are not prepared to sacrifice family life for their career firms in scandinavia try harder to attract mothers and then keep them le calv said women are now asking for some help or other benefits than salaries so instead of getting a company car or a raise in salary they say i want hours a week cleaning paid for by the company labour mp ruth kelly a member of the strong labour parliamentary womens group who wants parents to be paid a week to take three months leave said we need a complete rethink of our maternity and parental leave and this is what is going on at the moment at the dti we have the department of health saying on the one hand that it is wise to breastfeed your baby for the first six months and on the other hand we have maternity leave which means that after the first six weeks the statutory pay is only per week roger lyons general secretary of the manufacturing science and finance union said yesterday at the the national womens conference there is a disgraceful pay gap between men and women and most women suffer in silence from discrimination at work he said that the right for all workers to be represented by a union which comes into effect on june will benefit women especially

text: a heavilypregnant cherie booth yesterday proved herself a thorn in the governments side as she led an impassioned legal defence of the need to balance parenthood with working life in her last high court appearance before the birth of her fourth child due next week the prime ministers barrister wife declared on behalf of the tuc that government policy on parental leave was unlawful ms booth who recently hinted strongly that she wanted her husband to take paternity leave when their baby arrived spoke forcefully of allowing parents to strike a balance between work and family rights in a row over a new entitlement to parental leave the regulations which last year brought an eu directive into british law allow up to weeks unpaid leave to mothers and fathers of children under five but under pressure from employers organisations the government restricted this right to parents of children born after december last year the tuc bringing its case against the trade and industry secretary stephen byers claimed the privilege should also have been made available to all existing parents who had children under five on that date the legal battle highlights continuing tensions within mr blairs administration between the urge to keep business sweet and promoting familyfriendly working the government has also come under strong pressure not least from its own female backbenchers to provide some form of payment for parental leave amid warnings that few parents particularly fathers will otherwise take up the new right ms booth appearing with a team of three women barristers catering for any eventuality said the governments restriction had the effect of cutting off m parents from claiming the extra time with their children that was theirs by right she said it created a twotier system of parental leave those parents fortunate in having children born after december and other parents with similar age children born before that tony blair chose this week to reveal that while he would scale back his official workload he would not be taking paternity leave for the birth of the couples fourth child instead he is expected to hop up and down stairs between home and office cutting his working hours but by no means handing over his duties completely yesterday ms booth told the court that it was impossible to put a price on the loss to parents who miss out on time with their children what they are losing is the right to family life she said that is very difficult to quantify in monetary terms similarly unquantifiable were the benefits to employers of a familyfriendly policy a more contented workforce a more committed workforce ms booth told lord bingham the lord chief justice and mr justice morison who are not expected to pass judgment for a week that to include the parents of children under five born before december would cost employers about m on top of the projected m over five years these figures were small beer compared with the bn cost of the minimum wage regulations said ms booth the cost to employees of taking unpaid leave would be m in lost income much greater than the cost to employers the governments claim that the burden on employers was already excessive was an exaggeration she said jonathan crow counsel for the trade and industry secretary said the eu directive referred to the right of workers to parental leave on the grounds of the birth or adoption of a child therefore the entitlement to leave was triggered by the specific event of birth or adoption not by merely having responsibility for a child he said the tuc is likely to appeal if it loses the case and dti sources indicated the government might do the same if defeated tuc campaigners fear a worstcase scenario which would see the decision passed to the european court of justice effectively kicking the whole thing into the long grass according to one source

text: breakfast in the blair household must have been a tense affair this morning with the arrival of downing streets newest resident only days away cherie booth top employment lawyer and incidentally wife of the prime minister tony blair prepared to take on her husbands government in the high court over tuc claims that ministers have broken european law in excluding million working parents from new parental leave rights her husband meanwhile has just confided to the new york times that while he will reduce his workload around may the day his fourth child is due full paternity leave is not an option the first couples professional differences of opinion over familyfriendly working or worklife balance as the government now prefers to call it reflect tensions at the heart of the blair administration which have led to todays court case the row between unions and ministers centres on the fact that while the new labour government has gone much further than its tory predecessor in signing up to the european parental leave directive it has chosen to implement the law in a way many regard as minimal and deeply grudging the new right entitles each parent to take up to weeks off work to spend with their child up to its fifth birthday but the leave is unpaid and applies only to parents of children born before last december when the law was introduced ms booth qc in what will probably be her last court appearance before giving birth argued that the cutoff date was an unlawful restriction based on a false interpretation of the directive applying the right from december may be fine for the new blair baby but it excludes million working parents of older children according to the tuc including those parents in the scheme would cost employers around m which ms booth claimed was small beer compared with the bn cost of the minimum wage regulations the smart money is on ms booth and suggests that the government will lose the case although a judgment is not due for around a week either way the clash exposes the impossibility for the government of keeping business sweet the main concern of the department of trade and industry while simultaneously encouraging a familyfriendly culture in which parents are able to balance work and caring for their children those sympathising with the ministers dilemma should note that other eu countries have avoided becoming similarly bogged down in restrictions by opting from the first to abide by the spirit of the directive no other member state has attempted to introduce a cutoff date with the exception of ireland which has recently backed down after receiving an official opinion against the move from the european commission many other countries including italy and sweden have been more generous still making parental leave available to all working parents with children up to the age of eight britain however is still trying to reconcile two impulses aiming to achieve a culture change towards more familyfriendly working with the minimum of regulation tony blair can only become more aware of the stresses involved in that compromise as he rushes between baby and office attempting to make a go of his third way version of paternity leave

text: theres this woman i know a doctor with three children shes been the sole breadwinner for the past eight years ever since her husband who once did something in business was made redundant and became clinically depressed he was so low he couldnt be trusted with the children so she had to pay for a nanny too well eventually it got so bad she couldnt take it anymore she suggested a trial separation off he went and before she had finished paying that months bills he had set up house down the road with one of her childrens playmates mothers his depression disappeared just like that he told my friend that proved beyond doubt that she was the cause of it and then get ready for it he told her that it was only fair if she did something to make up for it he had an idea for a new business and according to this poor excuse for a husband it was up to my friend to find the startup money thats not the worst story ive ever heard i know someone else a mother of two whos having to sell the marital home she got in her divorce settlement to put herself through a threeyear training course her aim is to become financially independent but it will be years she thinks before she gets back to her premotherhood salary level or maybe it will take longer because now it emerges that her ex is going to stop maintenance the moment she starts drawing any salary at all why should he bankrupt himself to support an independent woman and heres another one about a man this time hes been paying the mother of his only child double the maintenance required by the courts for years without missing a payment round about the time this girl finished her exams and left home this man had to take early medical retirement that same month he got a letter from a solicitor to tell him that his wife did not just want child maintenance payments to continue ad infinitum she wanted them to be doubled her reason simple she needed the money she also deserved it if it hadnt been for his bad behaviour theyd never have had to get divorced in the first place everyone who knows them would say that shes more or less right on this count but how does that translate into pounds and pence this woman has a job for goodness sake a job with a pension thats what his friends say what her friends say is that one salary is just not enough to keep a household going this is also true so whats fair it used to be so simple a good exhusband was a man who supported his wife until such a time as she remarried and a good exwife was someone who used that support to carry on being a good mother to their children this is not to say that all or even most divorcing couples managed to hold to the ideal still we were fairly clear about how to assign blame when they didnt but now with so many women working and some men becoming primary carers the rules of this game have blurred our ideas of fair play have gone out the window no one seems to know exactly who is responsible for what one thing is clear though some people suffer greater losses post divorce than do others its long been known in policy circles that women are more likely to suffer a drop in income immediately following a divorce this is usually because they have care of the children and so cannot easily jump into fulltime work most courts in this country take a rehabilitative approach in such cases in other words they encourage settlements that offer mothers with care of their children stability in the shortterm while encouraging them to become selfsupporting in the long term this is more or less in line with what most of us would think of as fair but a new study of recently divorced parents written by alison perry and gillian douglas and commissioned by the family policy studies centre and the joseph rowntree foundation gives us a rather stark view of what happens next two years after divorce the incomes of most of the men in the study were the same as they had been when they were married but nearly half of the women had not returned to their preseparation income levels many were having to scramble and borrow money from their families and they were twice as likely as the men to say they were having trouble making ends meet while there was strong agreement about how important it was to give children stability by keeping them in their original home half of the parents had not had the resources to see this fine idea through for many the question defining the divorce settlement had not been how to share the assets but how to share the debts the most disturbing finding in the study was the haphazard way in which most couples made these settlements only a few had been able to get good professional advice early on most did not retain solicitors until very late in the day often this was to avoid antagonising the other party there was a tendency perhaps related to go for informal arrangements thus only a quarter of the mothers with care of children had maintenance in the form of a court order while received voluntary maintenance on a regular basis and nonresident fathers often helped out with mortgage payments clothes holidays school fees and so on dependence of such goodwill arrangements meant that many women were financially insecure the very worst news in this report is that most had not thought carefully about how they were going to support themselves in old age this must be partly due to the fact that most of the mothers in the study were in their s and s and so were more concerned about keeping shoes on their childrens feet and roofs over their heads but life goes on and divorce is forever a fair divorce settlement according to john cornwell senior partner at dawson cornwell should be not just about income and assets and maintenance but also about pensions and longterm security indeed pension sharing is becoming a reality but it is still the accepted norm for the man to walk away with his pension and for the woman to go for arrangements that allow her to keep her head above water in the shortterm often this is not because the wicked man is hoodwinking her but because she herself is not fully aware of the issues in other words a lot of women are losing out in their divorce settlements because they do not get good advice but they could if they and their husbands went into mediation according to sheena adam chief executive of national family mediation most people go into mediation with highly unrealistic ideas about how much the other party earns or how much they need to make ends meet one of the jobs of the mediator is to go for full disclosure the mediator then puts the facts on a flip chart so that both parties can see the gap between appearance and reality often a woman will have not been involved with finances up until this point if this is the case the mediator will try to give her a clear idea about how the finances work once there has been a balancing of power in the negotiations the aim then is to come to an agreement about how to share out the money and the responsibilities here again the key word is balance theres no winning or losing the aim is to come up with an arrangement thats fair there are not nearly enough mediators out there to give advice to divorcing parents when they need it if there were we wouldnt be having to spend so much time fretting about fairness and we wouldnt have so many stories about friends who are shafted by their moneygrabbing exes the questions of etiquette and proper conduct would remain it will probably be decades before we have a clear idea about what a fair settlement looks like in a world where both men and women work and both men and women also care for their children but most of the horror stories you hear of come about because people are nave about money or dont anticipate problems or make vague arrangements based on unarticulated assumptions and leave too much too goodwill its because they fail to protect themselves in the beginning that so many people find themselves being treated unfairly later on with proper assistance at the right time they can reach fair solutions that last

text: was it something i said last week i published a paper arguing that women lose out at work because they shoulder a disproportionate share of childcare responsibility and that employers knowing this rationally discriminate against them i therefore proposed that men be offered paternity leave which matches in time and money current maternity provision women and men would then compete on a level playing field the institute of directors said the plans would be devastating to business the telegraph argued that men werent interested anyway this newspaper described the scheme as close to utopian and a waste of legislative effort the tuc said it amounted to an attack on a better deal for working mothers the cabinet office said the report was nonsense most damning of all the department of trade and industry said it was a valuable contribution to the debate ouch rightwing criticisms are easily dealt with yes there would be some impact on business although not a large financial one as i suggest the paternity leave payments be reclaimed from the exchequer as maternity payments are the truth is that the shortestsighted and loudest end of the business lobby have opposed every move to increase time off for workers on the grounds that it would destroy businesses they are always wrong they said it about the fiveday week the eighthour day paid holidays extended maternity rights and parental leave the other argument made from the right but also by some feminists is that a mans place is not in the home because women are intrinsically better carers advocates of this view point out that it is widely held i suppose they mean in the same way that popular opinion was once against female emancipation the idea that men just arent built to care for children belongs in the dustbin of history the attacks from the left are trickier nobody in government or the trade unions is prepared to say publicly that so long as women take more time off than men employers have rational grounds for discrimination plenty of them agree in private needless to say but think admitting it openly would encourage employers in this behaviour i agree with you said one trade union official but you cant say it it plays into the hands of the right this is an absurd situation everyone knows it is happening but progressives close their eyes to it the cabinet office said it was nonsense to suggest that employers discriminate against women because of their role as mothers what employers are the cabinet office talking to has anybody put a lie detector on them we have to face up to the real impact of the gendered division of labour in our society and then do something about it the bias against women wont just go away no matter how hard we huff and puff the tuc description of my ideas as an attack on a better deal for working mothers was odd to say the least especially from john monks an intelligent forwardlooking man how does this square with my proposal for a doubling in the amount of time off available to parents at a cost of around bn a year helping working fathers is the best way to help working mothers by reducing their share of the domestic workload the tuc is an exemplary employer in this area offering male staff three weeks of paid paternity leave i simply want fathers who are not fortunate enough to be tuc employees to enjoy the same or greater rights the best argument against my scheme is that men will not take up the offered leave and that legislative and political energy should therefore go towards giving mothers more time off because theyll actually use it for the government introduces more generous paternity leave and men shun it no money or time will have been lost business will be as usual and i will have to eat a large slice of humble pie but i think i can glimpse a world where women and men meet as equals in the workplace and act as equals in the home maybe it is utopian i can live with that richard reeves is director of futures at the industrial possible familyfriendly has come to mean motherfriendly under this government said the industrial societys richard reeves it has further reinforced the divide between men who are seen not to have family responsibilities and women who are seen as having them mothers versus men to be published on wednesday will say that employment discrimination against women now makes more managerial and economic sense than ever before since labour was elected in a catalogue of policies has been promised to help working mothers maternity leave is soon expected to rise to one year from weeks some of which is paid the is believes that longer leave for mothers without a similar concession for fathers will make it even less attractive for companies to employ women since last december both men and women are also entitled to take up to weeks leave in the first five years of a childs life that change was introduced by european directive not by whitehall at least the political right who argue that women earn less because they have children have an intellectually coherent argument said reeves the government is peddling a fiction that women can be mothers at work competing equally with men the report will be accompanied by a survey showing that women with childcare responsibilities are treated much more sympathetically by employers who expect them to take time off but the price of tolerance is often lower pay and less training men who need to look after a sick child are likely to ring in sick themselves rather than admit that they have problems at home women are becoming intrinsically disadvantaged at work because of the role they are expected to perform as mothers said reeves men should be expected to take time off too the is will say that the only way to redress the balance is to provide equal treatment for parents regardless of sex however the cost of partly paid paternity leave for millions of fathers would almost certainly be opposed by the treasury if we are serious as a society about equality said reeves then we have to address the difference between the ability of mothers and fathers to compete in the workplace the government is taking an untenable position when it simultaneously calls for poundforpound gender equality in the workplace and in the next breath further cements women into a unique role as primary carers of children it doesnt add up tony blairs macho importance of fatherhood in terms of spending time with chil dren rather than just bringing in the money said reeves when he became a father again he said that being prime minister was the kind of job text: britains million workers have received a substantial boost in the last few years as a raft of employment law reforms set a minimum wage protected parttimers helped the disabled and introduced many other valuable benefits but for many workers the changes are theoretical and have not improved their lives perhaps the worst aspect of the employment infrastructure is a lack of enforcement by the government and a refusal by businesses to observe the new regulations the problem is huge says the low pay unit which sends floods of unhappy workers to get help from citizens advice bureaux employment law is getting so complex that many employees do not appreciate their own rights today for instance could be a red letter day for some women even though few probably realise it in a change to our notoriously complicated maternity rules many women whose babies were expected to be born from today will get a more generous entitlement to maternity pay and leave a new mother can now receive weeks pay and leave even if she has worked for her employer for less than two years until now those with shorter service were only entitled to weeks the maternity allowance a weekly payment for mothers earning between and a week also becomes more generous but claimants have to have pay slips going back for more than a year to calculate the amount due to them and many employers break the law by not issuing any one of the easiest issues to deal with is the minimum wage an hour for workers aged over and for those aged between and the inland revenue polices this legislation through a compliance department if an employer is paying too little workers can ring a hotline number and demand an investigation the revenue has put right many wrongs in this way but it takes a narrow view of its job if the employer has committed a breach of contract say by reducing an employees hours to meet the hourly rate threshold the revenue will not investigate the issue since superficially the law is being obeyed but having compliance officers is very rare for any legislation in most areas the only help given with enforcement by the government is the chance to claim at an employment tribunal jeff masters of the low pay unit says this is only a last resort informal ways of enforcing your rights are always the best ways the employment relationship is still a relationship going to an employment tribunal can be like taking a sledgehammer to crack a nut the advice bureaux tend to agree employers can turn nasty and dismiss you says one adviser so if you win in an employment tribunal it could be a pyrrhic victory and in most cases perhaps seven out of a worker will be looking for a reference which is going to be harder to get in these circumstances and the next employer might not look favourably on someone who took their last employer to a tribunal many employees who are getting shortchanged have little ability to fight back according to anna barlow of the acton law shop a free advisory service in west london their english might not be good or they might be working illegally a lot of people just decide to keep their head down and put up with it she says it is not just the traditional cowboy employers who are breaking the law a church cleaner of years standing recently accepted an outofcourt settlement from her employer a baptist church which was paying her only a week for work that she said took hours since the church also provided accommodation it regarded the payments to her as just pocket money many honest middle class families in britain may be shocked to discover that they are breaking the law in the way they deal with their cleaners even if they assume that ms mopp is selfemployed a tribunal could easily decide differently anna barlow who is dealing with one such claim now believes that people who retain cleaners or gardeners should pay the minimum wage give notice if they want to end the relationship and consider giving four weeks paid holiday a year it depends on the facts of each case she says the likelihood is that these issues wont be raised by the cleaners but if something goes wrong you could find yourself in front of a tribunal at the very least there should be a discussion with the cleaner about the issue of employment the good news for some employees is that certain issues can be resolved just by providing the employer with more information small businesses in particular may not appreciate the way the law has changed there is a common misapprehension for instance that employees do not get rights to paid holiday in their first three months of employment while it is true that they cannot claim paid holidays if they leave after three months they are entitled retrospectively to the full four weeks of paid holiday once they have been with the same employer for months barlow has found that many employers are happy to do the right thing in these circumstances once they know what it is many employees will get what is due only if they educate their bosses like all pieces of new legislation the regulations protecting parttimers will not have been implemented by all employers when they came into force at the beginning of july but they do provide the right for parttimers to have the same hourly pay rate as fulltimers doing the same job this sadly is where the law is letting down many people some jobs like those of school dinner ladies are only ever done on a parttime basis and this law has not been drawn up in a way that will help them it will take years for the employment revolution that started with these reforms to be completed those who want to benefit may have to find their own ways of enforcing the new laws low pay unit helpline work for mr d odgy if you do not want to be shortchanged by your bosses a good start is to recognise a cowboy employer and get out fast here are some of the signs of shady operators they operate under a range of business names there is headed notepaper in the office giving different business names for the same employer although you know them as smellie cars they also seem to do business as cowboy cabs and dodgy drivers although there could be innocent explanations they may also be specialists in running up debts under one limited company and then transferring the remnants of the business to another the name of the employer shown on your payslip is one you do not recognise you have rights which you can claim against your employer but if you have no knowledge of the m mouse ltd mentioned on your payslip you may have difficulty enforcing those rights in some unscrupulous setups people and companies are named as employers even though they live in a different country and have no real connection with the business sometimes they are merely the brother of the true owner which provides a useful escape route for anyone wanting to avoid debts they have run up they do not give you payslips you have a legal right to a payslip they are reluctant to give you the written employment contract which is your legal right since a contract sets out the basis for your relationship you are on very rocky territory if you do not have a written record of the basic terms bosses find it far easier to cut your hours or pay for instance if there is nothing on paper know your rights main employee protections your contract you have a basic right to a written employment contract giving details such as hours place of work and pay you are also entitled to pay slips pay anyone aged or over must be paid at least an hour rising to in october those aged to get a minimum of some groups are excluded among them au pairs prisoners and family members working in a family business sick pay you are entitled to receive statutory sick pay if you earn more than a week if your employer runs a more generous scheme than the statutory minimum a flat rate of a week you could get more holidays you are due four weeks paid holiday a year hours in most jobs you cannot be forced to work more than an average of hours a week but the rules are complicated there are many other rules on length of shifts working days and rights to breaks maternity pay the rules are a nightmare of complexity but all working mothers are entitled to weeks maternity leave most women will qualify for statutory maternity pay or maternity allowance many employers offer more generous schemes than the statutory minimum you cannot be discriminated against because you are pregnant or have a family although there are in reality many instances of women being fired parental leave if you have worked for your employer for more than a year you qualify for weeks of unpaid parental leave to be taken before your newborn is five although the rules apply to mothers and fathers few men are expected to take it since the leave is unpaid health and safety your employer should by law provide a healthy and safe working environment many employers even the largest ones are in breach of their obligations under the detailed hamps rules the tuc estimates that million people a year are injured at work discrimination discrimination on grounds of sex or race is unlawful although there are no special legal provisions to tackle discrimination on grounds of age religion or sexual orientation in theory there is no cap on the damages available through an employment tribunal but apart from a few headline cases damages are rarely spectacular the fact that women on average earn just per cent of male salaries is dealt with separately under the equal pay act the remedy is equal pay not unlimited damages redundancy there are intricate rules governing statutory redundancy pay for workers of two years standing the minimum depends on your age salary level and length of employment with that employer a person aged between and for instance will get one weeks pay capped at a week for each year of service many employers are more generous there are extensive rules on consultation where can i can get more information a new easytoread book your rights at work the tuc guide will be published by kogan page in september and available in bookshops the tuc runs a know your rights helpline on acas the advisory conciliation and arbitration service has local offices listed in the phone book its london inquiry number is the department of trade and industry provides information on many aspects of employment law see wwwdtigovuk or ring and ask for the orderline for its short employment law guides

text: women at a crowded fringe meeting at the labour conference this week were reassured to hear cherie booth say that she frequently discusses the balance between work and home life at the downing street kitchen table with her husband and teenage children what was less reassuring was how much of a constant struggle she found such a balance and how she suspected it probably always would be struggle may be a true description of the high profile blair household but it has been a central plank of the campaign for better maternity and paternity rights for more than two decades that there is no reason why it should be the case for millions of other families indeed campaigners argue that it is perfectly possible to remove the element of constant struggle from family life it is simply a matter of sensible policies there is no reason why participation in the labour market should be at the cost of children or marriages there is now clear evidence that the government has broadly accepted their case on the need for reform of maternity and paternity rights stephen byers trade and industry secretary who is leading the ministerial review on the issue admits that maternity rights provision is inadequate lagging up to years behind provision in many european states the battle is no longer over whether there should be reform but what form it should take it is at the birth of a child that these livability issues as they are known in political jargon are most sharply defined and the battle is greatest this is one of the most physically and emotionally demanding times of womens lives yet they are entitled to only six weeks leave at of their salary followed by statutory maternity pay of a week for weeks harriet harman labours most vocal champion of improved maternity rights argues that smp is too low for many of the poorest paid women in a report commissioned by the knitwear footwear and textiles union the former social security secretary said she found women factory workers returning to work six weeks after the birth often having to give up breastfeeding as a consequence their stories are heartrending said ms harman who is lobbying for one years paid maternity leave to be a labour manifesto pledge for the next election christine gowdridge of the maternity alliance pinpointed the most significant shift which policymakers had to recognise womens participation in the labour market was no longer for a bit of extra pin money but was a crucial contribution to the family income in the past years this change has accelerated in of women went back to work seven years later it had leapt to the significance for the policymakers is twofold first unless income is properly protected the leave is not taken britain is theoretically generous on maternity leave most women can take up to weeks but unless there are savings or a partners income that can support the family few women take the full entitlement people just cant afford to take time off if it is unpaid said richard dunstan of the national association of citizens advice bureaux unpaid leave was a perk for the rich said ms gowdridge so the priority for reform is more leave at full pay said the maternity alliance this argument is also used against unpaid parental leave the experience across europe has been that takeup rates particularly among men are poor unless it is paid properly this year ruth kelly labour mp for bolton west produced a pamphlet calling for a flatrated parental leave rate of a week which mr byers went out of his way to praise second the dramatic shift in womens work patterns has been crucial in persuading the chancellor gordon brown and the treasury that reform on maternity provision is needed what concerned the treasury was that women at the lowest end of the pay scale had the most inadequate rights higher earners benefit from contractual company schemes yet they are crucial to the governments commitment to end child poverty maryann stephenson of the fawcett society said enhanced maternity rights encourage women to stay in paid work and in the long run that saves the treasury money because women dropping out of the labour market are more likely to go on to benefits they are also not building up a pension plus if women take a break when they go back to work they take a job at a lower level and lower pay women workers end up being deskilled and that is a loss of productivity for the economy these arguments are likely to carry weight with mr byerss review because its remit gives priority to how maternity provision affects economic competitiveness and productivity what concerns child welfare campaigners is that the review does not include anyone with a child welfare brief either from the department of health or the home office they claim it makes nonsense of joinedup government campaigners fear that the government will miss the opportunity for radical reform because it is frightened by the business lobby which has declared its vehement opposition the government insists it will not allow business a veto but there are worrying signs that the review will come up with only some cheap symbolism two weeks of paid parental leave is one such option which campaigners say will do little to improve the lot of mothers

text: the equal pay act should be celebrating its th birthday this year what it is more likely to be doing is commiserating as study after study shows that british women who work fulltime still earn less than threequarters of mens salaries why a new report by the industrial society blames male managers the fact that most decision makers within organisations are male is likely to be perpetuating male ideas about the superiority of male working patterns and male performance at work claims the research may smith an occupational psychologist specialising in gender agrees men are still seen as the main breadwinners and women as secondary earners in consequence better paid jobs are given to men she says it doesnt help that most parttime workers are women she adds the ideal and therefore the best paid employee is seen as having a singleminded commitment to work prepared to work long hours and overtime whenever required the majority of people who have this attitude are men susan block of hay management consultants coaches women into higher salaries she blames the fact that being aggressive ambitious and pushy is often rewarded in men and criticised in women we cant win she says if were too assertive we are seen as not doing our job properly because weve got ideas above our station and if were too nice which women are in fact socialised to be in the workplace we are seen as a pushover both help leave women at the bottom of the pay and promotion pile the equal opportunities commission believes women suffer at two levels on an individual basis they are paid differently for the same job and on a collective level womendominated professions are almost always paid less than maledominated professions says chair julie mellor secretarial work is a classic example its only since men have reentered the field that salaries are rising significantly confirms a spokesperson for the recruitment consultancy manpower research consistently shows however that despite these discrepancies women tend to be less preoccupied with salary and status than men instead women are often more concerned with job satisfaction and receiving nonfinancial perks such as familyfriendly hours and ongoing training says marilyn davidson professor of managerial psychology at the university of science and technology in manchester this means that unlike men they often dont ask for salary increases and in todays marketplace if you dont ask you dont get worse still the industrial society report points out its simply not the done thing to ask someone what salary theyre on unless you share a house or better still a bedroom even at job interviews potential recruits squirm in their seats at the very thought of bringing up the money factor the result is that you are left without a clue what your secretarial colleague ben is paid and in turn your employer is able to get away with paying you significantly less than him in fact universums latest survey claims this veil of secrecy surrounding paypackets means that todays female graduates are more likely than ever to expect and therefore to demand less than men the survey found the average woman anticipates earning a month less than her male peers in her first job and a staggering a month less five years later it gets worse as she gets older says a spokeswoman for the industrial society in her early s a woman earns about of a mans pay in her s in her s and in her s employees should be confident enough to share their personal salary details with each other as a way of exposing discriminatory pay gaps she concludes if from such discussions you suspect you are being paid less because youre female ask your personnel department to provide you with a scatter diagram showing the spread of pay identified by sex so that you can see where you are then advises the industrial society objectively assess your strengths and capability in relation to the organisations needs its a good idea to get a colleague a male one is helpful to get a different perspective to help you make that assessment at this point use your information from personnel on pay together with salary figures for similar posts in the job pages to set yourself a reasonable target figure for what you think you should be paid openness is key adds block when you next go for an interview ask directly about pay and when youre talking about your achievements dont say we achieved studies show one of the reasons men get higher salaries is because they sell themselves saying i achieved

text: its a typical slice of daily life at the palmfringed hub of the new economy a workplace undoubtedly but one where an unusual definition of work holds sway engineers are chasing each other down the hallways firing softtipped darts from nerf guns their programmer colleagues are busy playing table football or hunched over videogames and when real work begins it is as likely to take the form of a bug bash where programmers stay in the office long into the night until they have fixed a certain number of glitches in the system as it is a conventional meeting or at least this is what the male ones are doing these are scenes from valley of the boys a documentary by monika khushf director of engineering at the software company intuit which alarmed many by demonstrating just how maledominated silicon valleys working culture really is khushf interviewing male and female engineers from major technology companies including sun microsystems apple computers and netscape portrayed a workplace where men spend long hours weekends included constructing elaborate model cities in lego while their female colleagues look on depressed or simply resigned theyre having a great old time one woman told khushf and im sitting there going oh please these women would not be surprised by a new list of the most influential people in the valley compiled by the san jose mercury its leading newspaper not one woman made the top and in britain were no better our three biggest internet companies freeserve the auction site qxl and the software firm autonomy have one woman director between them in any sector this would be a cause for concern but in the supposedly revolutionary crucible of ebusiness where casually attired workers pride themselves on abandoning the hangups of the old economy it is little short of a disaster its not as if there arent any women entrepreneurs to begin with according to the national foundation of women business owners the number of womenowned businesses in the us has more than doubled in the past decade indeed american women seem positively fuelinjected when it comes to startups they are launching businesses at twice the rate of their male counterparts but it is becoming increasingly clear that the old boys network that has been consigned to history is being replaced by a new one focused on the venture capitalists who provide the speculative backing for the valleys big ideas insiders like to portray the new economy as running on little but caffeine and ideas but of course deep down it runs on cash and here a new boys network is vigorously asserting itself according to venture one an organisation that provides information to venture capitalists only of the total venture capital funding in the states goes to companies with women chief executives of the venture capitalists currently working in the us only are women says diana reid of the san franciscobased forum for women entrepreneurs you do the math as they say in san jose reid and others are starting to mobilise the valleys women in a movement that includes women in technology international which holds an annual silicon valley summit in santa clara and a range of incubators such as the san franciscobased womens technology cluster which aims specifically to nurture technology startups run by women not that you will ever get anyone in the politicsfree valley to admit to being an activist we dont consider ourselves to be an affirmativeaction group says reid were just trying to jumpstart excellent business plans in britain the situation is even worse when it comes to venture capital funding lucy marcus who set up hightechwomencom to support women in technologyrelated fields by mentoring and networking says there are a pitiful number of women venture capitalists working in london i can name them without running out of fingers she says launched in march this year high techwomen already boasts members recent months have also witnessed the launch of busygirlcouk the first business technology portal dedicated to women internet entrepreneurs and webgrrlsorguk another networking organisation in the uk getting vc finance is made more difficult because the vcs in town have always been traditional city boys of the oldschool network says may chong of webgrrls they are men who have very little experience of doing business with women let alone women who are younger and more techy than them the bestknown american exception to all this is carly fiorina the chief executive of hewlettpackard and the first woman to head one of americas largest companies as measured by revenues recently named by fortune magazine as the most powerful woman in business she sees the gender divide as part of a wider problem of conformity exactly the personality trait that most valley entrepreneurs expend energy trying to deny diversity needs to become a priority in the hitech industry fiorina says right now there is a virtual wall between available talent and available jobs diversity is not a hiring practice nor a hiring priority in many silicon valley companies this combined with the lessthanopen perspective of many hiring managers means says fiorina that this industry has far too much conformity strenuous attempts are being made to change things the american computer experience for example offers free places to girls on its computer camps predictably computer summer camps are dominated by boys only of campers are girls other educational projects seek to educate the educators surveys show that girls are put off computing by dull programming classes dominated by nerdy boys nursing violent videogames and an inability to communicate in anything other than computer programming languages wendy tan is one of the lucky british women to be shown the money at she is the founder and chief executive of moonfruit a service provider specialising in websitebuilding tools in my career its so normal being the only woman that you dont notice it any more she says of the businesses in the investment portfolio of their major backer the investmentfund firm europweb tan says she is the only female boss ultimately the valleys unstoppable appetite for talent may force change says carolyn leightton founder and chair of women in technology international as the demand for talented technologists grows and the supplies continue to shrink those companies which are committed to removing the barriers for the advancement of women will certainly be the winners although it may be drowned out by the sound of the tablefootball games and the nerfgun shootouts a quiet revolution may soon become an economic necessity

text: employers should put an end to a burnout britain where millions of employees work the longest hours in europe and should stop whinging about red tape john monks tuc general secretary said yesterday his call came as the tucs annual congress demanded fresh legislation to boost workers rights including measures to protect staff from unpaid overtime worth at least bn to employers each year text: bored with lining your bosss pockets want to work for a company you feel is doing some good in the world join the club according to the institute of business ethics ibe support staff are joining the rapidly swelling ranks of uk workers who are turning their backs on employers with no sense of moral responsibility with last weeks news that the government is to drop its ethical foreign policy there are likely to be even more of them taking it into their own hands to ensure that employers lacking values are employers lacking loyal staff says simon webley ibe research director but if the foreign office finds it too difficult to stick to its commitments how easy is it for the support worker to find a truly ethical employer the voluntary sector is perhaps the most obvious port of call and one of the most popular voluntary services overseas vso has just announced a record number of applications an indication that workers are looking for a job that does more than just pay the bills the most common reasons given were the wish to give something back and a need for personal fulfilment explains matthew bell vsos director of communications but bills do need to be paid and the financial rewards in the voluntary sector will barely cover your weekly groceries let alone your rent or mortgage the vsos national recruitment campaign launched earlier this year was upfront about job prospects lawyers wanted salary per annum and yes you did read that correctly even paid posts within charities and indeed the public sector can offer far lower salaries than average thats why says webley its good news that more and more private businesses are introducing a code of business ethics something that shows staff and prospective staff just how seriously they are taking their moral responsibilities a typical code will address corporate policy towards its various stakeholders employees shareholders customers suppliers and the wider public standards relating to suppliers for example are likely to include a commitment to ensuring that there is no child labour at any stage of its supply chain and that wages and working hours are reasonable meanwhile standards relating to staff might include policies on what to do if you are offered products such as stationery that you suspect have been made by exploiting workers in developing countries as part of their code some companies such as campa have set up a trust to send inspectors on regular visits to check the ethical standards and practices of all suppliers whether in east london or the far east other employers including marks amp spencer and monsoon have joined the ethical trading initiative eti a membership body that focuses purely on setting standards for labour within supply chains explains david steele its information officer nevertheless research shows that a few employers do write a code of ethics simply to look good upon closer inspection there may be little real commitment thats why its so important for valuesdriven secretaries to ask at the interview stage not only whether there is a code but whether you can see it advises rachel ormond an academic researcher in ethics and employment it will always exist in document form and increasingly it is included on the company website and in the annual report you might also want to ask whether your prospective employer encourages staff to get involved in giving something back to society she adds employees may do voluntary work for example either wholly or partly in company time and usually on projects initiated by the company allied dunbar sends staff on onemonth secondments to help with projects in india and at mamps hour parttime secondments are set up for staff to help with local community projects which are carried out over threemonth periods so important are employers ethics becoming to todays jobseeker that research shows that they are often the deciding factor when a candidate opts for a particular post in reality pay and training tend to be a higher priority for support staff says a spokesperson for recruitment consultancy manpower but because its a jobseekers market at the moment they can often take those two for granted the etis david steele claims that media coverage has encouraged workers to take a broader interest in the companies for which they work there has been a recent influx of documentaries and features highlighting conditions in factories overseas as well as on issues like child labour in this country he says the fact that the internet has created a global economy is also significant we no longer think of a sweatshop in korea as being so far away a spokesperson for recruitment agency adecco adds a further reason jobseekers have a greater choice in selecting companies they respect and share common values with more employers are going ethical every day the result is that if youre a secretary who wants to work in say the city you can now pick a company that you know invests in environmental projects robert weston founder of groundswell an ethical business consultancy explains organisations approach us not only asking how do we become more values driven but how can we be seen to be valuesdriven the second question comes from employers knowledge that to sell their product and to attract the best recruits they have got to have clearcut values shell is one company that has had to work particularly hard at reassessing its approach following past controversies concerning the disposal of the brent spar oil platform and the companys activities in nigeria last year the company unveiled a new ethical advertising campaign in part aimed at improving its image among prospective employees we want to be seen as a company willing to confront these often difficult issues not sweep them under the carpet a company spokeswoman explains sue jenkins pr manager at triodos a bristolbased bank which invests exclusively in organisations with social and environmental objectives believes that after the greedoriented s there has been an inevitable move towards giving most of our candidates now apply because of our values she says jane de bude pa to the managing director at triodos is one such person she left her last position as a legal secretary for a large solicitors firm after she became disheartened by their lack of ethics i work hard here she admits but i believe wholeheartedly in what i do i feel im putting something back into society rather than just concentrating on how much money i or my employers make it has made a huge difference to my level of job satisfaction in the end predicts alex macgillivray deputy director of the new economics foundation ethical issues will become so crucial in the recruitment process that instead of a bunch of wellknown good companies there will be a blacklist of notoriously bad ones few will want to be listed among the latter already according to the ibe of the ftse companies have a code of business ethics further information the institute of business ethics wwwibeorguk ethical trading initiative wwwethicaltradeorg voluntary services overseas wwwvsoorguk triodos wwwtriodoscouk

text: almost a quarter of the british workforce is now forced to work at some point between pm and am the price being paid for an american inspired society open hours a day seven days a week is turning out for millions to be antisocial working hours at little or no extra pay fifteen per cent are working all night the number of workers on duty during the hours of darkness will be confirmed in a report this week highlighting the potential dangers to children of being passed like batons in a relay race between shiftworking parents sixtyone percent of working families now have parents away from home during early mornings evenings nights and weekends per cent have a parent who works at weekends the numbers are expected to double by its clear that employers are expecting staff to work whatever hours are needed without seeing these as exceptional circumstances said megan pacey of the daycare trust which will publish shift parents this week there has also been an erosion of premium payments for working outside the old ninetofive hours so people often receive no extra money for this either staff are now required to work antisocial hours in a swath of industries far beyond the traditional fields of restaurants and hotels the decline in hour working expected with the contraction of manufacturing industry has been replaced instead by an explosion in the number of call centres shops and newtechnology businesses operating around the clock tom ingham from dorking in surrey who works as an information processor for an accounting firm said im now required to work one week in four through the night we receive extra pay for doing it but its highly disruptive to family life my partner is tied down every evening with the kids and i feel shattered its difficult enough sleeping in the day anyway but i am almost always disturbed as well by the children in the house i also end up drinking a huge amount of coffee which keeps me on edge for hours he added working these shifts is virtually nonnegotiable everyone in our department has to do it you simply wouldnt expect to get promoted or pay reviewed if you didnt the biggest increase in late working in the past five years has come from the retail sector thirtysix stores in the strong sainsburys chain already open all night on at least one evening a week in december the number will be increased to staff are paid a premium for working on sundays or if their shift covers the hours between midnight and am however they receive no extra pay if obliged to work until midnight or to start in the early hours we are now a hour business even if a store is not actually open said a spokeswoman for the chain there is rarely a time when there isnt a skeleton staff on duty at the very least professor sue yeandle of sheffield hallam university a leading labourmarket expert said the clear trend towards people working into the evening and overnight will continue its certainly true that with a small number of exceptions people are not getting paid a premium even without overnight working the development of the entire service sector in late afternoons and into the evening is very disruptive to family life people in these sectors on relatively modest incomes are simply not able to buy proper childcare to cover these hours on their pay there are clear risks to children but middleclass families are suffering from long hours syndrome too judy mella a surgical registrar in dorset is a single mother with four children she is expected to be on call usually on site at least one night a week its part of the job it means i have to have someone to come in and spend the night at home it has meant employing an au pair who absorbs a third of my takehome pay bensummerskillobservercouk how parents can help ages do use junk mail to get your children interested in reading play ball games with your children and get them to think about the reason a ball moves at different speeds help your childrens maths by getting them to count loose change see which bath toys sink and which float ask the child to think about why pgt teenagers do help your children with homework and get them to set a timetable take them on trips to historic houses get videos out that relate to school projects dont sit your children in front of the tv while you do something else do their homework for them cost of lost sleep not getting enough sleep can lead to you becoming borderline retarded falling an hour short of the necessary eight hours can temporarily knock a point of your iq fifteen points can easily be lost in a week if you miss two hours a night the average nights sleep in britain is now down to seven hours from nearly nine in the early part of the last century many people survive on less than six hours a night ten per cent of us have fallen asleep while driving causing a quarter of all fatal road accidents in a survey per cent of train drivers admitted having nodded off at the controls in american schoolboy randy gardner stayed awake for hours a full days and had periods of lucidity until the end he still holds the world record for staying awake

text: the government has caved in to demands from big business and scrapped plans to give mothers the right to return to work parttime after maternity leave the observer can reveal in a blow to labours attempts to woo women voters stephen byers trade secretary will next month rule out the proposal when he unveils a new green paper on family friendly policies baroness jay the womens minister had pressed hard for the right to be included in labours next election manifesto campaigners for women and the family last night condemned the move as a capitulation to heavy lobbying from business organisations labour women mps will also be concerned that male members of the cabinet have again overruled the advice of both jay and her deputy tessa jowell on a key family policy however sources
