text: workaholic habits are damaging productivity and playing havoc with families attempts to improve their worklife balance the government warned yesterday in the first official report on the social consequences of excessive overtime one in nine fulltime employees works more than hours every week mostly men with children and one in eight regularly works both saturdays and sundays the survey found most men wanted more flexible arrangements such as jobsharing and a reduced working week but twothirds thought working part time would damage their careers most women said they would rather work more flexibly after the birth of a child than have longer maternity leave but almost half the employers thought this would be regarded as unfair by the rest of their staff the government billed the survey as the first and largest research into worklife balance in britain it was based on interviews with employees employers and company head offices margaret hodge the equal opportunities minister said the problem facing industry was not absenteeism but presenteeism the long hours culture is alive and kicking we are all working too long hours and it is making us ill that doesnt help productivity and it certainly doesnt support families mrs hodge was disappointed that overtime had increased since when the government introduced the eu working time directive stopping most firms from making staff work more than hours a week we need to ask why introduction of the hour week has not led to greater change in hours of work and presenteeism but the government was encouraged that of employers in the survey agreed it could be acceptable in some circumstances for staff to switch to part time working the survey found of men who lived as a couple with dependent children worked more than hours a week this compared with of women in the same family circumstances of single parents and of people who were single or members of childless couples the long hours of many males in couple households with children may reflect both a need for income associated with children and the opportunity to work long hours associated with the presence of a partner the report said almost half the employers offered stress counselling but only gave assistance with childcare it feels as if we are dealing with the consequences and not the cause of people not getting the right balance between work and the rest of their lives mrs hodge said but the good news was that of employers let staff vary their hours of employees work flexitime and have arranged to work only during term time john monks general secretary of the tuc said bad employers would not be forced to cut long hours until there were changes in the law the one thing the government could do is announce its intention not to renew the individual opt out to the working time directive which sees many people work excessively long hours john edmonds general secretary of the gmb union said it is right that we should hold a carrot out to the thousands of good employers but it is time that the government showed a willingness to wave a stick at the bad ones peter elwood chief executive of lloyds tsb and chairman of employers for worklife balance said we recognise that men need to balance their work and life outside work just as much as women mrs hodge who admitted working incredibly long hours said men had been excluded from previous campaigns for a better worklife balance now fathers too are calling for a better deal with of fathers working over hours every week it means that men are less and less able to spend the time with the family that they want worklife balance survey by institute for employment research university of warwick and iff research page summary report from dfee publications rural bliss in a hitech haven fortunately im branch offices and i came back to work four months after having each child the hours lawyers work have increased dramatically especially in london it is because of client demand and increased text: the problem i have been offered a new job on a two year contract it is in the same field i work in now which i love and ill be earning more a year for less work but i am worried about losing my permanent contract ive tried to persuade my present employers to pay me more but they refuse despite freely admitting they will readvertise my post at the salary i am requesting now so i dont know what to do its all complicated by the fact that i got married this year and my husband and i want a baby within the next couple of years with my present job i have all the stability years of service pension maternity benefits i could want the solution what a dilemma if you had no ties or commitments then it might be easier to pack in a steady job for a better one with a less certain future however your desire to start a family does complicate things a little but dont forget that you will still have some maternity rights in the new job you can take weeks of unpaid statutory maternity leave regardless of length of service once you have worked for your new employer for twentysix weeks ending with the fifteenth week before our due date you can normally claim statutory maternity pay as well for weeks speak to acas number in your phone book for more advice on maternity rights so what you do really depends on what plans you think you might have if and when a baby arrives for example some new mothers are happy to take six weeks off after the birth and go straight back to work others want six months and some want to stay with their child until she starts school more commonly women often decide to go back to work parttime your partners financial situation is also an issue could he support you for a while if the baby arrived at the end of the two year contract and how would you feel about jobhunting towards the end of your contract if you were heavily pregnant the bottom line is that you dont know what the future holds you might get pregnant within the next two years you might not you might find yourself out of work at the end of the two year contract but you might not if you stay put you might get a rise but you might not the only certainties are that you are currently overworked and undervalued but secure and have an opportunity to improve your conditions but at a cost security is the risk of insecurity a greater stress than the overwork you have now only you can decide dr sandi mann is author of psychology goes to work purple house and managing your boss in a week hodder amp stoughton advice given to this problem should only be regarded as a text: once upon a time corporate man cared who had the biggest desk whether he was allocated a parking space and how often the boss asked him for a drink after lengthy office hours now no more what the majority of male employees apparently hanker after is a small corner of home in which they can do their business alone according to the first of a series of studies commissioned by the department for education and employment worklife balance published today a quarter of men already work from home and a further would like to do so among women work from home and a further wish to follow in their footsteps the survey which questioned employees and employers indicates that only of workers prefer being homebased because of childcare most people want to become more effective employees the survey part of the governments attempt to encourage us all to get a life and therefore also save the billions of pounds now being forked out on ill health and absenteeism reaffirms that the british unlike many other europeans cant get enough of work onefifth of employees put in more than hours a week of them fathers oneeighth work both saturday and sunday and almost of employees who work extra hours do so without pay part of the reason for this devotion to duty is that britain is dominated by small and mediumsized businesses more than half of which employ fewer than workers if you work alongside the boss it becomes all that much harder to watch the clock another part of the reason is selfpreservation and job insecurity theres not much point in getting a life if you then have no money with which to enjoy it the worklife debate is also not as the government perhaps inadvertently implies genderblind as peter moss of london university points out it raises yet again the wicked issues the way in which in the workplace time the valuation of care and the importance of production and reproduction have a profoundly different impact on men and women it is telling that far fewer women than men in todays dfee survey wish to work from home why first because as relative newcomers to the workplace their confidence is arguably less a survey published in the summer by management today magazine indicated that of working mothers believe that presenteeism dominates the culture of work families can ruin your career in the same survey of women said there were times when work was a welcome refuge from home compared with only of men why because of course home means something very different to females than it does to their male partners paid work in the home for men may mean precisely that for women it means dealing with children and domesticity as they have always done but even more so because they no longer have the office break one of the ironies of the worklife balance debate of course is that the solution most strongly pushed flexibility can when too narrowly defined add to the burden of women rather than diminish it what it should mean for instance is termtime and parttime work without forfeiting a career or training opportunities what it becomes too often in practice is working long hours for less money if parttime staggered over unsocial times such as nights and weekends and an end to job satisfaction the dfees survey tells us that one in five employees works for companies open hours a day in europe academics such as eviatur zerubavel acknowledge that the time squeeze and the creation of a new worklife balance affect women most acutely and that all parts of society have to contribute to the solutions employers included for instance in holland some companies offer time banks employees accrue time instead of cash bonuses which they can use when they please in britain only of companies offer modest sabbaticals since men now also regularly take time off women are no longer penalised in their careers when for instance they go on maternity leave according to todays survey while almost half of employees are likely to be offered stress counselling to cope with the long hours culture only are offered assistance with basic childcare needs the government is loath to press employers to do more whether on childcare or in creating a different culture yet according to professor shirley dex of cambridge university an end to the longhours culture would cause almost no financial or organisational costs but produce a number of benefits including retention of staff employers of course know the arguments well yet until the government gets tougher and male employees more demanding worklife balance will continue to be viewed as mainly a female employees problem one for the girls to sort out as best they can commenttheguardiancom

text: public sector employers have an enviable reputation for providing equality of opportunity for women but the private sector is catching up the national management salary survey by the institute of management and consultancy remuneration economics shows that of women are at director level in the private sector compared with in the public sector and a groundbreaking study of women chief executives in local government sponsored by pricewaterhousecoopers has shown that female public sector managers feel as vulnerable and isolated as they did years ago according to the research women still feel judged by their physical appearance rather than their ability and it seems that what a senior woman wears is as important as what she does at work pam fox joint author of the study with mike broussine and a visiting research fellow at the university of west of england tells of an aspiring chief executive who overheard a member of a selection panel say you can tell shes hard by the shape of her lips she adds that men and women perceive senior women as lacking charisma and presence especially if they are physically small or younglooking thats not all the equal pay act has been in force for years in december but womens pay in the public sector still falls well short of equality the latest figures drawn from shows public sector women still earning only of the salary of their male colleagues only teachers with a strong national pay structure and an industryspecific review board come anywhere close to parity at across local government from social services to environmental health and from waste disposal to clerical work traditional divisions of labour persist along gender lines women are overrepresented in professions that rarely make it to the top such as social care and human resources and while a growing number of women are entering public accountancy and law common backgrounds for public sector chief executives relatively few make it to the top of their professional tree but the foxbroussine research also found that women are making up their own rules for career advancement and that can only be good news for men and women alike no longer forced down a traditional path of unbroken career advancement many new women at the top have moved from one employment sector to another gaining valuable experience as they go wider perspective one example is stella manzie chief example of the newly formed unitary local authority in west berkshire a cambridge graduate with a degree in english manzie has worked for the nowdefunct association of county councils and also as private sector management consultant the fact that i dont come from a particular professional background has given me a wider perspective she says my private sector experience taught me to deliver work to a tight timescale and on budget and has given me credibility so how can senior and aspiring women make that allimportant career move rita sammons a former president of the society of chief personnel officers in local government suggests that women take time out to develop themselves and their career get involved in national projects highprofile partnerships and network she says if you raise your profile people will remember you there are still so few senior women around sammons suggests that women should aim high the next step is probably easier than you think if it isnt decide what support you need to get there public sector headhunters agree with her and advise women to be more demanding when they look for career advancement maurice smart from local government headhunters tmp worldwide says that too few women ask for the help theyre entitled to if you apply for a job through a professional recruitment consultancy make sure you get measured feedback both on your application and your interview performance he says women often understate their achievements on their cv and dont include enough hard facts smart suggests that women need to make sure their cv works hard for them dont be shy about telling a future employer about budgets youve managed productivity gains youve achieved or changes youve made he says ask for advice on how to tailor your application to the vacancy for further information on the research project contact pamfoxbusinessfreeservecouk

text: it is time we started talking up residential childcare the evidence is that working in childrens homes requires some of the highest skills and personal qualities in social care most children who need support remain with their own families or in foster care and the numbers in residential care have greatly reduced the result of this good policy is that young people in childrens homes have usually had very damaging experiences and may have had their difficulties compounded by failures in other parts of the care system the media and the public need very little information to understand that the work is hard and demanding but this is rarely offered why is residential care so stigmatised it is undeniable that some workers betrayed those they were entrusted to care for and that it took young people rather than professionals in the main to reveal the appalling abuse nothing can put right the fact that some of those young people paid with their lives and others with a lifetime of lost opportunities but a bad press for residential childcare has persisted for years in spite of evidence including evidence from young people and their families that good residential care can be liberating and can keep family relationships healthy behind the bad image is a belief often held by others in social care that only familybased care is good for children and this may be combined with a suspicion that anyone wanting to nurture other peoples children outside a family is at least odd and at worst a potential abuser finally there is the apparently high cost of residential care apparently because other parts of the care system are not fully costed and the longer term costs of poor care in terms of careers in crime poor physical and mental health and low educational achievement are not taken into account familybased care is what the vast majority of children need but a whole range of support is necessary to tailor support to specific needs residential childcare is a small but significant resource when used well it can prevent the breakdown of family relationships and offer some young people an option they prefer we are reaching the point when staff doing the most skilful job in social care are being undermined by public criticism and pinned down by rigid procedures the very relationships between staff and young people that create the possibility for the young person to flourish are increasingly hard to maintain because of the ways staff have to operate to survive expert practitioners tend to leave when they cannot do the job well the risk is that we will replace them with staff who can do no more than hold on to young people for long enough for them to fend for themselves as young adults if this happens it will confirm them on a path toward social exclusion there are hopeful signs examples of high quality residential childcare do exist they focus on outcomes a respect for human rights and the young peoples values they have a commitment to a philosophy and model of therapeutic working more investment will be going into residential childcare training and this group of staff will be among the first registered with the general councils new legislation is extending the time for supporting young people when they leave care this should reduce the effects on vulnerable young adults of the sudden withdrawal of support when they move out of residential homes these positives could start to stop the rot in residential childcare

text: parents would be paid to stay at home for up to three years to look after small children under plans to be scrutinised by the chancellor gordon brown the former social security secretary harriet harman has written to him calling for mothers to be offered a toddler tax credit to enable them to spend the first three years of childrens lives at home the money which would subsume the child care tax credit paid to working single mothers and low income couples to pay for childcare could be extended to fathers or even grandparents and apply to all but the highest earners the payment should be linked to womens average income of a week although ms harman has not cited a specific sum some childcare organisations think it should be up to a week ms harman the chair of the childcare commission believes the financial support could prove a vote winner with women and portray labour as the true party offering mothers the stayathome choice the government is considering increasing statutory maternity pay to a week to enable more new mothers to stay at home for longer if we genuinely support parental choice in how they care for their infants we should pay for it she said under her toddler tax credit scheme mothers would receive income from the government which they could use for a variety of options the mother or father could stay at home or the money could enable both to work part time to share the care of the child a grandparent could be paid but more controversially the money could also be used to pay for childcare replacing child care credit it would prove most helpful for women in low income families forced back to work early because of maternity pay currently worth just a week ms harmans plan has not yet been addressed by the chancellor according to a treasury spokesman but last night drew support from family rights pressure groups christine gowdridge director of the maternity alliance said anything that genuinely enables people to choose between work and home without losing too much income would be really helpful

text: angela roberts left home at l following difficulties with her parents now and recovering from a drink problem she has a threeyearold daughter nicole and a new baby callum ms roberts has lived independently since the age of and has had three different tenancies but has consistently run into financial problems until now i had a key meter for the gas which i couldnt always afford to charge i had no bed for nicole and i was totally stressed with worry i wasnt coping she confessed but then she saw a sign at the brunswick for the living skills course and signed up when young people get flats for the first time they dont know where to go for cheap things and that was my downfall she said now i know all the cheapest shops in town and i use them i manage on a week for the three of us ive just had my benefit cut because the child support agency says i havent told them enough about nicoles father the truth is that i didnt get the forms they insist they sent me so i have to watch every penny i use secondhand shops for cots and things like that and put something in my bank account every week for the children in january im going back to college so i can get a decent job and support them

text: oliver smyth is chortling gently as he plays with his lego on the floor blue eyes wide open he grasps a farmyard fence and rushes to give it to his mother one of the family cats slips in and he scampers after it caught up in the joy of being two years old the smyths home is testament to a much longed for child from the numerous photos and jumbled toys to the letter fridge magnets spelling his name yet when he arrived his mother rosie a yearold nursing assistant for an nhs community trust in the west country was granted just days maternity leave in contrast to the weeks given to most new mothers the reason is that oliver is adopted and at present adoptive parents have no statutory right to paid maternity leave it is an issue which the government last week announced it will address after a threemonth consultation on the green paper on work and parents the trade and industry secretary stephen byers admitted that he had been unaware of the discrepancy and signalled his determination to change this rosie and her husband nigel who are waiting to adopt again do not want her to return to work again after six weeks as she was forced to through financial necessity and so in the first case of its kind they have successfully used the human rights act to claim that their child was being discriminated against and force her employer to offer adoptive parents the same maternity leave as birth parents sense of injustice rosies realisation that her employers an nhs community health trust would treat her differently to birth mothers came when she approached them after hearing that she could adopt oliver as a fourmonthold in the spring of the issue of maternity leave had not occurred to her before she had been too preoccupied with three failed ivf attempts she was surprised by the response i was told there was a draft policy agreement that gave six weeks on half pay but that since the board had not approved it it was up to individual managers to choose whether to implement it her managers did not implement the draft policy but offered days special leave for family reasons an appeal to a second manager who had adopted a child brought a further six days but the offer fell a long way short of the eight weeks on full pay and weeks on half pay offered to birth mothers with olivers arrival imminent rosie and nigel felt they were in no position to fight rosie borrowed money and enjoyed a mere six weeks with her baby before she was forced to return to work parttime she said my bosses offered me more unpaid leave they werent going to force me back before i was ready but money was leaving oliver was she admitted very hard it wasnt fair and i thought it was particularly unfair on him i thought the trust was discriminating against him as a baby he was denied the chance to have a fulltime mum for the same amount of time as any other baby she said the sense of injustice continued to rankle and it did not help when a colleague became pregnant all the time i was aware that she and her baby would have weeks together while my baby and i just had three weeks she said with the realisation that she would want to adopt again she began months of campaigning writing to politicians and her union unison she argued that maternity leave was important to allow her to bond with her baby sympathy was offered but the message was the same maternity leave in the words of the department of social security was offered to protect women from the exertions of work immediately prior to giving birth and to allow a period of rest immediately following the exertion of childbirth and then she had a breakthrough on the advice of a judge she contacted a family lawyer who told her that her employer as a public authority forced to adhere to the european convention on human rights may have breached article of the human rights act deprived of mothers time the article is quite broad and bans discrimination on grounds not only of sex race and social origin but birth explained chris hall of crosse amp crosse solicitors oliver as an adopted child appeared to have been discriminated against because he was being deprived of time with his mother that a child with a birth mother would have had a human rights barrister at matrix backed up this view arguing that it was given force because article of the act covering the right to family life also appeared to have been flouted faced with being sued under the human rights act the trust changed its mind and offered six weeks paid leave at ninetenths of her salary followed by weeks on half pay plus the equivalent of statutory pay the policy may not have been quite equal to that for birth mothers and oliver may not have had his mother at home for weeks but at least it would apply to their next adopted child the chief executive of british agencies for adoption and fostering felicity collier said this is an issue that we are concerned about as it restricts the number of people coming forward to adopt the success of adoption will depend on how successful those first few months are when a child joins your family it is vitally important there is time for at least one parent to be at home with the child

text: even if the options for making life easier for working parents contained in the governments recent green paper were all taken up parents in the united kingdom would still receive less help and protection at work than those in almost every other country in europe when it comes to maternity rights parental leave and pay while taking time off to look after children this country is and will remain a long way behind its neighbours the trade secretary stephen byers is proposing modest changes to existing rights things like extending the right to unpaid maternity leave to a year or increasing the flat rate of statutory maternity pay now per week there are also limited rights to work reduced hours for either or both parents after having a child these are balanced by ideas to help make the law and the administration of maternity pay simpler for employers and the possibility of exemptions for some small businesses but labour has made quite clear that not all of the proposals will be implemented employers employees and other interested groups are invited to indicate their top three priorities on a list they have until march to respond to put the proposals in perspective sweden offers days of paid leave per family which can be taken all at once or used to reduce working hours norway offers weeks of fulltime leave paid at of earnings germany france and spain offer fulltime leave for new parents until their child is three years old which in the first two countries can also be used to work parttime belgium has three months fulltime or six months parttime leave backed by a careerbreaks scheme of up to six years the uk was the last country in the european union to introduce parental leave years after a draft ec directive was first proposed and years after sweden even the us was quicker with the family and medical leave act in only five other eu members offer no form of payment for people taking family leave all of them offer earningsrelated maternity pay for longer than the six weeks given in the uk most of them also have wellestablished rights for men and women to work reduced or flexible hours after having a baby this has been fiercely resisted here so far by employers the proposal that got the most media attention was that men should be offered the right to two weeks paternity leave possibly paid at the per week rate the recognition that caring for children is not just the mothers responsibility and that men might need financial help from the government to be able to take a bigger caring role is significant certainly all the evidence from elsewhere in europe is that entitlements to leave are not taken by men in any numbers unless it is paid and paid at a high enough rate to replace earnings from work the big question is why the state should get involved coming from the department of trade and industry the green paper focused mainly on productivity and the business case for changing the law parents especially women need help to balance work and family care because otherwise they and their skills will be lost to employers and the economy either because they have to give up work or because they work less efficiently refreshingly the green paper does offer as one of its goals safeguarding the health and welfare of the mother and child before and after birth the wellbeing of children or elderly dependants of working people often gets lost in todays debate over worklife balance and familyfriendly employment burdens on business usually get more attention the state will get involved because having a child is more than a lifestyle choice it is something special that deserves help and support from employers and the rest of society but should businesses carry the costs of losing staff should childless text: oliver smyth is chortling gently as he plays with his lego on the floor blue eyes wide open he grasps a farmyard fence and rushes to give it to his mother one of the family cats slips in and he scampers after it caught up in the joy of being two years old the smyths home is testament to a much longed for child from the numerous photos and jumbled toys to the letter fridge magnets spelling his name yet when he arrived his mother rosie a yearold nursing assistant for an nhs community trust in the west country was granted just days maternity leave in contrast to the weeks given to most new mothers the reason is that oliver is adopted and at present adoptive parents have no statutory right to paid maternity leave it is an issue which the government last week announced it will address after a threemonth consultation on the green paper on work and parents the trade and industry secretary stephen byers admitted that he had been unaware of the discrepancy and signalled his determination to change this rosie and her husband nigel who are waiting to adopt again do not want her to return to work again after six weeks as she was forced to through financial necessity and so in the first case of its kind they have successfully used the human rights act to claim that their child was being discriminated against and force her employer to offer adoptive parents the same maternity leave as birth parents sense of injustice rosies realisation that her employers an nhs community health trust would treat her differently to birth mothers came when she approached them after hearing that she could adopt oliver as a fourmonthold in the spring of the issue of maternity leave had not occurred to her before she had been too preoccupied with three failed ivf attempts she was surprised by the response i was told there was a draft policy agreement that gave six weeks on half pay but that since the board had not approved it it was up to individual managers to choose whether to implement it her managers did not implement the draft policy but offered days special leave for family reasons an appeal to a second manager who had adopted a child brought a further six days but the offer fell a long way short of the eight weeks on full pay and weeks on half pay offered to birth mothers with olivers arrival imminent rosie and nigel felt they were in no position to fight rosie borrowed money and enjoyed a mere six weeks with her baby before she was forced to return to work parttime she said my bosses offered me more unpaid leave they werent going to force me back before i was ready but money was leaving oliver was she admitted very hard it wasnt fair and i thought it was particularly unfair on him i thought the trust was discriminating against him as a baby he was denied the chance to have a fulltime mum for the same amount of time as any other baby she said the sense of injustice continued to rankle and it did not help when a colleague became pregnant all the time i was aware that she and her baby would have weeks together while my baby and i just had three weeks she said with the realisation that she would want to adopt again she began months of leave in the words of the department of social security was offered to protect women from the exertions of work immediately prior to giving birth and to allow a period of rest immediately following the exertion of childbirth and then she had a breakthrough on the advice of a judge she contacted a family lawyer who told her that her employer as a public authority forced to adhere to the european convention on human rights may have breached article of the human rights act deprived of mothers time the article is quite broad and bans discrimination on grounds not only of sex race and social origin but birth explained chris hall of crosse amp crosse solicitors oliver as an adopted child appeared to have been discriminated against because he was being deprived of time with his mother that a child with a birth mother would have had a human rights barrister at matrix backed up this view arguing that it was given force because article of the act covering the right to family life also appeared to have been flouted faced with being sued under the human rights act the trust changed its mind and offered six weeks paid leave at ninetenths of her salary followed by weeks on half pay plus the equivalent of statutory pay the policy may not have been quite equal to that for birth mothers and oliver may not have had his mother at home for weeks but at least it would apply to their next adopted child the chief executive of british agencies for adoption and fostering felicity collier said this is an issue that we are concerned about as it restricts the number of people coming text: tony blair has given the goahead for a neardoubling of statutory maternity pay in the most radical changes to parental rights since the second world war mothers will be offered a week to stay at home with their newborn babies a huge increase on the current a week the move which would cost the state an estimated m extra a week is designed to slash the number of new mothers who return to work early because they are unable to survive on the current figure more than half of new mothers return before the weeks of paid leave to which they are entitled with citing money as the reason the plan widely welcomed by family groups is among proposals in the governments green paper on work and parents published yesterday it seeks to bring britains provision for working parents into line with scandinavian and other eu states the consultation document suggests that working mothers should have the right to stay at home for a year after their childs birth with paid maternity leave extended from to weeks unpaid breaks could last up to months instead of the present weeks and fathers could be given two weeks paternity leave paid at the same rate as mothers both parents could have the option of sharing unpaid maternity leave in a surprise move calculated to woo women voters mothers could also have the right to work reduced hours for up to a year after their childs birth the flexible working could continue when maternity leave ends although small businesses could be exempt large businesses could also be let off if they can prove that their business would be unduly disrupted the reduced hours plan which the womens ministers tessa jowell and baroness jay and the employment minister margaret hodge had pressed hard for during a ministerial review process had been widely expected to be dropped in the face of opposition from big business but ministers believe it is the key to retaining the third of women who do not return to work after giving birth at a cost to employers of a worker or m a year to the economy i think this is the most important issue ms hodge said we need to find a way of reconciling the business interests with the interests of a lot of mothers and what a lot of women want is more flexible working hours nearly half of all working women have children under five with the figure likely to be by launching the paper the trade and industry secretary stephen byers said the review group had been surprised to learn that adoptive parents had no maternity rights they would be able to take paid leave in line with birth parents he said he described the worklife balance as one of the key issues facing us in a modern society and insisted that the system had to change the labour market has changed dramatically over the last years and the status quo is not an option we need to give support and assistance to parents but in a way that business will recognise as important he said the employment services would be encouraged to train more temporary replacements for small businesses while cash advances would be offered to cover employers maternity pay theres an opportunity where we can marry both being a good parent and a good employee the proposals out for consultation until march were widely welcomed the maternity alliance praised the governments determination to move things forward the equal opportunity commission said it showed a commitment to supporting families the confederation of british industry said flexible employment practice should be encouraged not regulated and said extending maternity leave and offering paternity leave would hit small businesses

text: stephen byers the modernising trade and industry secretary who relishes his reputation as one of new labours most enthusiastic cheerleaders is an unlikely radical within weeks of taking up his cabinet post mr byers issued the provocative declaration that wealth creation was more important than wealth redistribution hardly the sentiments of a reformer however his green paper on parental rights published yesterday does have a radical edge which would usher in the most significant changes since the second world war in this contentious area the prospect of a near doubling in statutory maternity pay and an extension of unpaid maternity leave to allow a woman to stay at home for a year would go a long way towards taking britain closer to more generous arrangements in europe at the launch of his green paper yesterday mr byers demonstrated his new found credentials as a radical when he declared that britain was way off pace on parental rights the status quo is not an option he said mr byers is not however about to abandon his role as a modernising blairite the wideranging recommendations in the green paper are balanced with concessions to business in the hope of persuading organisations such as the cbi to drop their opposition to reform showing their devotion to the blairite third way mr byers and the womens minister baroness jay spoke of their relish for the challenge of winning over business leaders the two ministers who launched their green paper at a small london business happy computers are embarking on a twopronged offensive to sweet talk business in the first place carrots are to be offered to persuade business leaders that they will not be overburdened with red tape a generous compensation package will help businesses cope with the costs of administering new schemes businesses are also to be offered an advance on maternity payments to ensure cash flow is not jeopardised the second element of the ministerial charm offensive is to persuade businesses that improving parental rights is in their interests improved rights will they say lead to more effective and more loyal employees mr byers detailed his thinking when he spoke of a new opportunity to marry together the goal of being a good parent with being a good employee in the classic language of blairism he added we should not see them as being in conflict his soothing language appeared to fall on deaf ears when the cbi and the british chambers of commerce voiced strong misgivings about the reforms the bcc complained of the cumulative burden imposed on them by the government however one minister who has been closely involved in the review compared the negotiations to the battle over the minimum wage we are at the same stage with business on parental rights that we were with the minimum wage five years ago the minister said business was very hostile to the minimum wage then but no one is opposed now some critics will argue that ministers have gone too far in appeasing business leaders severe restrictions have been placed on the right to parttime work this has been renamed reduced hours and employers are to be given a veto if they can prove that their business would be damaged by an employee moving away from fulltime work despite misgivings voiced by the equal opportunities commission the governments reforms will ensure that labour stands on a significantly more radical platform at the next general election labour was famously pilloried for its manifesto which adopted a safety first approach across a whole range of issues but one minister said the reforms to parental rights which will be a key element of labours manifesto will show that new labour now has the courage to be more ambitious we had to be cautious in the run up to the last election because we had to persuade people we were competent the minister said we have now achieved that which means we can now be more ambitious and set out a real agenda for the second term our parental reforms give us a onceinageneration opportunity to do something really radical the green paper in full

text: tony blair has given the goahead for a neardoubling of statutory maternity pay in the most radical changes to parental rights since the second world war mothers will be offered a week to stay at home with their newborn babies a huge increase on the current a week the move which would cost the state an estimated m extra a week is designed to slash the number of new mothers who return to work early because they are unable to survive on the current figure more than half of new mothers return before the weeks of paid leave to which they are entitled with citing money as the reason the plan widely welcomed by family groups is among proposals in the governments green paper on work and parents published yesterday it seeks to bring britains provision for working parents into line with scandinavian and other eu states the consultation document suggests that working mothers should have the right to stay at home for a year after their childs birth with paid maternity leave extended from to weeks unpaid breaks could last up to months instead of the present weeks and fathers could be given two weeks paternity leave paid at the same rate as mothers both parents could have the option of sharing unpaid maternity leave in a surprise move calculated to woo women voters mothers could also have the right to work reduced hours for up to a year after their childs birth the flexible working could continue when maternity leave ends although small businesses could be exempt large businesses could also be let off if they can prove that their business would be unduly disrupted the reduced hours plan which the womens ministers tessa jowell and baroness jay and the employment minister margaret hodge had pressed hard for during a ministerial review process had been widely expected to be dropped in the face of opposition from big business but ministers believe it is the key to retaining the third of women who do not return to work after giving birth at a cost to employers of a worker or m a year to the economy i think this is the most important issue ms hodge said we need to find a way of reconciling the business interests with the interests of a lot of mothers and what a lot of women want is more flexible working hours nearly half of all working women have children under five with the figure likely to be by launching the paper the trade and industry secretary stephen byers said the review group had been surprised to learn that adoptive parents had no maternity rights they would be able to take paid leave in line with birth parents he said he described the worklife balance as one of the key issues facing us in a modern society and insisted that the system had to change the labour market has changed dramatically over the last years and the status quo is not an option we need to give support and assistance to parents but in a way that business will recognise as important he said the employment services would be encouraged to train more temporary replacements for small businesses while cash advances would be offered to cover employers maternity pay theres an opportunity where we can marry both being a good parent and a good employee the proposals out for consultation until march were widely welcomed the maternity alliance praised the governments determination to move things forward the equal opportunity commission said it showed a commitment to supporting families the confederation of british industry said flexible employment practice should be encouraged not regulated and said extending maternity leave and offering paternity leave would hit small businesses the green paper in full
